<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Etymology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Beijing" title="Names of Beijing">Names of Beijing</a></div>
<p>Over the past 3,000 years, the city of Beijing has had <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Beijing" title="Names of Beijing">numerous other names</a>. The name <i>Beijing</i>, which means "Northern Capital" (from the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">北</span></span> for <i>north</i> and <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">京</span></span> for <i>capital</i>), was applied to the city in 1403 during the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a> to distinguish the city from <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> (the "Southern Capital").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-minggov_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-minggov-38">[37]</a></sup> The English spelling <i>Beijing</i> is based on the government's official <a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Chinese" title="Romanization of Chinese">romanization</a> (adopted in the 1980s) of the two characters as they are pronounced in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_Mandarin" title="Standard Mandarin">Standard Mandarin</a>. An older English spelling, <i>Peking</i>, was used by Jesuit missionary <a href="/wiki/Martino_Martini" title="Martino Martini">Martino Martini</a> in a popular atlas published in Amsterdam in 1655.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[38]</a></sup> Although Peking is no longer the common name for the city, some of the city's older locations and facilities, such as <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Capital_International_Airport" title="Beijing Capital International Airport">Beijing Capital International Airport</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/International_Air_Transport_Association_code" title="International Air Transport Association code">IATA Code</a> PEK, and <a href="/wiki/Peking_University" title="Peking University">Peking University</a>, still retain the former romanization.
</p><p>The single Chinese character abbreviation for Beijing is <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%BA%AC" title="wikt:京">京</a>, which appears on automobile license plates in the city. The official <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">Latin alphabet</a> <a href="/wiki/Standardization_Administration_of_China" title="Standardization Administration of China">abbreviation</a> for Beijing is "BJ".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Beijing" title="History of Beijing">History of Beijing</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Early history">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The earliest traces of human habitation in the Peking municipality were found in the caves of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dragon_Bone_Hill" title="Dragon Bone Hill">Dragon Bone Hill</a> near the village of <a href="/wiki/Zhoukoudian" title="Zhoukoudian">Zhoukoudian</a> in <a href="/wiki/Fangshan_District" title="Fangshan District">Fangshan District</a>, where <a href="/wiki/Peking_Man" title="Peking Man">Peking Man</a> lived. <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_erectus" title="Homo erectus">Homo erectus</a></i> fossils from the caves date to 230,000 to 250,000 years ago. <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" title="Homo sapiens">Homo sapiens</a></i> also lived there more recently, about 27,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[40]</a></sup> Archaeologists have found <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">neolithic</a> settlements throughout the municipality, including in <a href="/wiki/Wangfujing" title="Wangfujing">Wangfujing</a>, located in central Peking.
</p><p>The first <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Chinese_urban_planning" title="Ancient Chinese urban planning">walled city</a> in Beijing was <a href="/wiki/Jicheng_(Beijing)" title="Jicheng (Beijing)">Jicheng</a>, the capital city of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_of_Ji" title="State of Ji">state of Ji</a> and was built in 1045 BC. Within modern Beijing, Jicheng was located around the present <a href="/wiki/Guang%27anmen" title="Guang'anmen">Guang'anmen</a> area in the south of <a href="/wiki/Xicheng_District" title="Xicheng District">Xicheng District</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-42">[41]</a></sup> This settlement was later conquered by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_of_Yan" title="State of Yan">state of Yan</a> and made its capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[42]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Imperial_China">Early Imperial China</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Early Imperial China">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tianning_Temple_Pagoda.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4896" data-file-width="3672" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Tianning_Temple_Pagoda.jpg/170px-Tianning_Temple_Pagoda.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Tianning_Temple_Pagoda.jpg/255px-Tianning_Temple_Pagoda.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Tianning_Temple_Pagoda.jpg/340px-Tianning_Temple_Pagoda.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tianning_Temple_Pagoda.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pagoda_of_Tianning_Temple_(Beijing)" title="Pagoda of Tianning Temple (Beijing)">Tianning Pagoda</a>, built around 1120 during the <a href="/wiki/Liao_dynasty" title="Liao dynasty">Liao dynasty</a></div></div></div>
<p>After the <a href="/wiki/Qin_Shi_Huang" title="Qin Shi Huang">First Emperor</a> <a href="/wiki/Qin%27s_wars_of_unification" title="Qin's wars of unification">unified China</a>, Jicheng became a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zhou_(region)" title="Zhou (region)">prefectural capital</a> for the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hist_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-hist-1">[1]</a></sup> During the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Three_Kingdoms_period" title="Three Kingdoms period">Three Kingdoms period</a>, it was held by <a href="/wiki/Gongsun_Zan" title="Gongsun Zan">Gongsun Zan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yuan_Shao" title="Yuan Shao">Yuan Shao</a> before falling to the <a href="/wiki/Cao_Wei" title="Cao Wei">Wei Kingdom</a> of <a href="/wiki/Cao_Cao" title="Cao Cao">Cao Cao</a>. The AD 3rd-century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(265%E2%80%93420)" title="Jin dynasty (265–420)">Western Jin</a> demoted the town, placing the prefectural seat in neighboring <a href="/wiki/Zhuo_Prefecture" title="Zhuo Prefecture">Zhuozhou</a>.
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Sixteen_Kingdoms" title="Sixteen Kingdoms">Sixteen Kingdoms</a> period when northern <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> was conquered and divided by the <a href="/wiki/Five_Barbarians" title="Five Barbarians">Wu Hu</a>, Jicheng was briefly the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Xianbei" title="Xianbei">Xianbei</a> <a href="/wiki/Former_Yan" title="Former Yan">Former Yan</a> Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rene_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rene-44">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>After China was reunified during the <a href="/wiki/Sui_dynasty" title="Sui dynasty">Sui dynasty</a>, Jicheng, also known as <a href="/wiki/Zhuo_Commandery" title="Zhuo Commandery">Zhuojun</a>, became the northern terminus of the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Canal_(China)" title="Grand Canal (China)">Grand Canal</a>. Under the <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a>, Jicheng as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Youzhou" title="Youzhou">Youzhou</a>, served as a military frontier command center. During the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/An-Shi_Rebellion" title="An-Shi Rebellion">An-Shi Rebellion</a> and again amidst the turmoil of the late Tang, local military commanders founded their own short-lived Yan dynasties and called the city <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yanjing" title="Yanjing">Yanjing</a>, or the "Yan Capital." Also in the Tang dynasty, the city's name Jicheng was replaced by Youzhou or Yanjing. In 938, after the fall of the Tang, the <a href="/wiki/Later_Jin_(Five_Dynasties)" title="Later Jin (Five Dynasties)">Later Jin</a> ceded <a href="/wiki/Sixteen_Prefectures" title="Sixteen Prefectures">the frontier territory including what is now Beijing</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Khitan_people" title="Khitan people">Khitan</a> <a href="/wiki/Liao_dynasty" title="Liao dynasty">Liao dynasty</a>, which treated the city as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liao_Nanjing" title="Liao Nanjing">Nanjing</a>, or the "Southern Capital", one of four secondary capitals to complement its "Supreme Capital" Shangjing (modern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baarin_Left_Banner" title="Baarin Left Banner">Baarin Left Banner</a> in <a href="/wiki/Inner_Mongolia" title="Inner Mongolia">Inner Mongolia</a>). Some of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_pagodas_in_Beijing" title="List of pagodas in Beijing">oldest surviving pagodas in Beijing</a> date to the Liao period, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pagoda_of_Tianning_Temple_(Beijing)" title="Pagoda of Tianning Temple (Beijing)">Tianning Pagoda</a>.
</p><p>The Liao fell to the <a href="/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(1115%E2%80%931234)" title="Jin dynasty (1115–1234)">Jurchen Jin dynasty</a> in 1122, which gave the city to the <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song dynasty</a> and then retook it in 1125 during its <a href="/wiki/Jin%E2%80%93Song_Wars" title="Jin–Song Wars">conquest of northern China</a>. In 1153, the Jurchen Jin made Beijing their "Central Capital", or <a href="/wiki/Zhongdu" title="Zhongdu">Zhongdu</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hist_1-2"><a href="#cite_note-hist-1">[1]</a></sup> The city was besieged by <a href="/wiki/Genghis_Khan" title="Genghis Khan">Genghis Khan</a>'s invading <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">Mongolian army</a> in 1213 and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Zhongdu" title="Battle of Zhongdu">razed to the ground</a> two years later.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-economist-45">[44]</a></sup> Two generations later, <a href="/wiki/Kublai_Khan" title="Kublai Khan">Kublai Khan</a> ordered the construction of <a href="/wiki/Khanbaliq" title="Khanbaliq">Dadu</a> (or Daidu to the Mongols, commonly known as <a href="/wiki/Khanbaliq" title="Khanbaliq">Khanbaliq</a>), a new capital for his <a href="/wiki/Yuan_dynasty" title="Yuan dynasty">Yuan dynasty</a> to the northeast of the Zhongdu ruins. The construction took from 1264 to 1293,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hist_1-3"><a href="#cite_note-hist-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist_45-1"><a href="#cite_note-economist-45">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[45]</a></sup> but greatly enhanced the status of a city on the northern fringe of <a href="/wiki/China_proper" title="China proper">China proper</a>. The city was centered on the <a href="/wiki/Drum_Tower_and_Bell_Tower_of_Beijing" title="Drum Tower and Bell Tower of Beijing">Drum Tower</a> slightly to the north of modern Beijing and stretched from the present-day <a href="/wiki/Chang%27an_Avenue" title="Chang'an Avenue">Chang'an Avenue</a> to the northern part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Line_10,_Beijing_Subway" title="Line 10, Beijing Subway">Line 10 subway</a>. Remnants of the Yuan <a href="/wiki/Rammed_earth" title="Rammed earth">rammed earth</a> wall still stand and are known as the Tucheng.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ming_dynasty">Ming dynasty</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Ming dynasty">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BeijingWatchTower.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="478" data-file-width="573" decoding="async" height="184" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/BeijingWatchTower.jpg/220px-BeijingWatchTower.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/BeijingWatchTower.jpg/330px-BeijingWatchTower.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/BeijingWatchTower.jpg/440px-BeijingWatchTower.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BeijingWatchTower.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>One of the corner towers of the <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_City" title="Forbidden City">Forbidden City</a>, built by the <a href="/wiki/Yongle_Emperor" title="Yongle Emperor">Yongle Emperor</a> during the early <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a></div></div></div><p>
In 1368, soon after declaring the new <a href="/wiki/Hongwu_Emperor" title="Hongwu Emperor">Hongwu era</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red_Turban_rebellion" title="Red Turban rebellion">rebel</a> leader <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zhu_Yuanzhang" title="Zhu Yuanzhang">Zhu Yuanzhang</a> captured Dadu/Khanbaliq and razed the Yuan palaces to the ground.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-patbu_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-patbu-48">[47]</a></sup> Since the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Yuan_dynasty" title="Northern Yuan dynasty">Yuan</a> continued to occupy <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xanadu,_China" title="Xanadu, China">Shangdu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>, Dadu was used to supply the Ming military garrisons in the area and renamed Beiping (<a href="/wiki/Wade%E2%80%93Giles" title="Wade–Giles">Wade–Giles</a>: Peip'ing, "Northern Peace").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[48]</a></sup> Under the Hongwu Emperor's feudal policies, Beiping was given to his son <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zhu_Di" title="Zhu Di">Zhu Di</a>, who was created "<a href="/wiki/Prince_of_Yan" title="Prince of Yan">Prince of Yan</a>".</p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijings_layout_genom_historien.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="591" data-file-width="748" decoding="async" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Beijings_layout_genom_historien.jpg/220px-Beijings_layout_genom_historien.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Beijings_layout_genom_historien.jpg/330px-Beijings_layout_genom_historien.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Beijings_layout_genom_historien.jpg/440px-Beijings_layout_genom_historien.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijings_layout_genom_historien.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Overlapping layout of Beijing during the Liao, Jin, Yuan and Ming dynasties</div></div></div>
<p>The early death of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zhu_Yuanzhang" title="Zhu Yuanzhang">Zhu Yuanzhang</a>'s heir led to a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jingnan_Campaign" title="Jingnan Campaign">succession struggle</a> upon his death, one that ended with the victory of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zhu_Di" title="Zhu Di">Zhu Di</a> and the declaration of the new <a href="/wiki/Yongle_Emperor" title="Yongle Emperor">Yongle era</a>. Since his harsh treatment of the Ming capital <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Yingtian</a> (modern <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a>) alienated many there, he established his fief as a new co-capital. The city of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beiping" title="Beiping">Beiping</a> became Beijing ("Northern Capital") or <a href="/wiki/Shuntian_Prefecture" title="Shuntian Prefecture">Shuntian</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WDL1_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-WDL1-50">[49]</a></sup> in 1403.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-minggov_38-1"><a href="#cite_note-minggov-38">[37]</a></sup> The construction of the new imperial residence, the <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_City" title="Forbidden City">Forbidden City</a>, took from 1406 to 1420;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist_45-2"><a href="#cite_note-economist-45">[44]</a></sup> this period was also responsible for several other of the modern city's major attractions, such as the <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Heaven" title="Temple of Heaven">Temple of Heaven</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[50]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tian%27anmen" title="Tian'anmen">Tian'anmen</a>. On 28 October 1420, the city was officially designated the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a> in the same year that the Forbidden City was completed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hymes_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hymes-52">[51]</a></sup> Beijing became the empire's primary capital, and Yingtian, also called <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> ("Southern Capital"), became the co-capital. (A 1425 order by Zhu Di's son, the <a href="/wiki/Hongxi_Emperor" title="Hongxi Emperor">Hongxi Emperor</a>, to return the primary capital to Nanjing was never carried out: he died, probably of a heart attack, the next month. He was buried, like almost every Ming emperor to follow him, in an <a href="/wiki/Ming_tombs" title="Ming tombs">elaborate necropolis</a> to Beijing's north.)
</p><p>By the 15th century, Beijing had essentially taken its current shape. The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_city_fortifications" title="Beijing city fortifications">Ming city wall</a> continued to serve until modern times, when it was pulled down and the <a href="/wiki/2nd_Ring_Road" title="2nd Ring Road">2nd Ring Road</a> was built in its place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[52]</a></sup> It is generally believed that Beijing was the largest city in the world for most of the 15th, 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[53]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_China" title="Christianity in China">first known church</a> was constructed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jesuit_China_Missions" title="Jesuit China Missions">Catholics</a> in 1652 at the former site of <a href="/wiki/Matteo_Ricci" title="Matteo Ricci">Matteo Ricci</a>'s chapel; the modern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Immaculate_Conception_in_Beijing" title="Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Beijing">Nantang Cathedral</a> was later built upon the same site.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>The capture of Beijing by <a href="/wiki/Li_Zicheng" title="Li Zicheng">Li Zicheng</a>'s peasant army in 1644 ended the dynasty, but he and his <a href="/wiki/Shun_dynasty" title="Shun dynasty">Shun court</a> abandoned the city without a fight when the <a href="/wiki/Manchu_people" title="Manchu people">Manchu</a> army of Prince <a href="/wiki/Dorgon" title="Dorgon">Dorgon</a> arrived 40 days later.
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Qing_dynasty">Qing dynasty</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Qing dynasty">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Scenery_of_Longevity_Hill.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1872" data-file-width="2816" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Scenery_of_Longevity_Hill.JPG/220px-Scenery_of_Longevity_Hill.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Scenery_of_Longevity_Hill.JPG/330px-Scenery_of_Longevity_Hill.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Scenery_of_Longevity_Hill.JPG/440px-Scenery_of_Longevity_Hill.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Scenery_of_Longevity_Hill.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Summer_Palace" title="Summer Palace">Summer Palace</a> is one of the several palatial gardens built by Qing emperors in the northwest suburb area.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Dorgon" title="Dorgon">Dorgon</a> established the <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing dynasty</a> as a direct successor of the Ming (delegitimising <a href="/wiki/Li_Zicheng" title="Li Zicheng">Li Zicheng</a> and his followers)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica_ming_qing_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-britannica_ming_qing-56">[55]</a></sup> and Beijing became China's sole capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[56]</a></sup> The Qing emperors made some modifications to the Imperial residence but, in large part, the Ming buildings and the general layout remained unchanged. Facilities for Manchu worship were introduced, but the Qing also continued the traditional state rituals. Signage was bilingual or Chinese. This early Qing Beijing later formed the setting for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Four_Great_Classical_Novels" title="Four Great Classical Novels">Chinese novel</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Dream_of_the_Red_Chamber" title="Dream of the Red Chamber">Dream of the Red Chamber</a></i>. Northwest of the city, Qing emperors built several large palatial gardens including the <a href="/wiki/Old_Summer_Palace" title="Old Summer Palace">Old Summer Palace</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Summer_Palace" title="Summer Palace">Summer Palace</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hata-men_Gate.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1113" data-file-width="1583" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Hata-men_Gate.jpg/220px-Hata-men_Gate.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Hata-men_Gate.jpg/330px-Hata-men_Gate.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Hata-men_Gate.jpg/440px-Hata-men_Gate.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hata-men_Gate.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Chongwenmen" title="Chongwenmen">Chongwenmen</a>, a gate to the inner walled city, c. 1906</div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Second_Opium_War" title="Second Opium War">Second Opium War</a>, Anglo-French forces captured the outskirts of the city, looting and burning the <a href="/wiki/Old_Summer_Palace" title="Old Summer Palace">Old Summer Palace</a> in 1860. Under the <a href="/wiki/Convention_of_Peking" title="Convention of Peking">Convention of Peking</a> ending that war, Western powers for the first time secured the right to establish <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Legation_Quarter" title="Beijing Legation Quarter">permanent diplomatic presences</a> within the city. From 14 to 15 August 1900 the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Peking_(1900)" title="Battle of Peking (1900)">Battle of Peking</a> was fought. This battle was part of the <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Rebellion" title="Boxer Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a>. 
The attempt by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boxers_(group)" title="Boxers (group)">Boxers</a> to eradicate this presence, as well as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_christian" title="Chinese christian">Chinese Christian</a> converts, led to Beijing's reoccupation by eight <a href="/wiki/Eight-Nation_Alliance" title="Eight-Nation Alliance">foreign powers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[57]</a></sup> During the fighting, several important structures were destroyed, including the <a href="/wiki/Hanlin_Academy" title="Hanlin Academy">Hanlin Academy</a> and the (new) <a href="/wiki/Summer_Palace" title="Summer Palace">Summer Palace</a>.
A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peace_agreement" title="Peace agreement">peace agreement</a> was concluded between the <a href="/wiki/Eight-Nation_Alliance" title="Eight-Nation Alliance">Eight-Nation Alliance</a> and representatives of the Chinese government <a href="/wiki/Li_Hongzhang" title="Li Hongzhang">Li Hung-chang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yikuang" title="Yikuang">Prince Ching</a> on 7 September 1901. The treaty required China to pay an indemnity of US$335 million (over US$4 billion in current dollars) plus interest over a period of 39 years. Also required was the execution or exile of government supporters of the Boxers and the destruction of Chinese forts and other defenses in much of northern China. Ten days after the treaty was signed the foreign armies left Peking, although legation guards would remain there until <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>With the treaty signed the <a href="/wiki/Empress_Dowager_Cixi" title="Empress Dowager Cixi">Empress Dowager Cixi</a> returned to Peking from her "tour of inspection" on 7 January 1902 and the rule of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qing" title="Qing">Qing</a> dynasty over China was restored, albeit much weakened by the defeat it had suffered in the Boxer Rebellion and by the indemnity and stipulations of the peace treaty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[59]</a></sup> The Dowager died in 1908 and the dynasty imploded in 1911.
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Republic_of_China">Republic of China</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Republic of China">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chiang_KaiShek_Portrait_Tiananmen_Beijing.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="635" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="175" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Chiang_KaiShek_Portrait_Tiananmen_Beijing.jpg/220px-Chiang_KaiShek_Portrait_Tiananmen_Beijing.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Chiang_KaiShek_Portrait_Tiananmen_Beijing.jpg/330px-Chiang_KaiShek_Portrait_Tiananmen_Beijing.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Chiang_KaiShek_Portrait_Tiananmen_Beijing.jpg/440px-Chiang_KaiShek_Portrait_Tiananmen_Beijing.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chiang_KaiShek_Portrait_Tiananmen_Beijing.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A large portrait of <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a> was displayed above <a href="/wiki/Tiananmen" title="Tiananmen">Tiananmen</a> after <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WWII" title="WWII">WWII</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The fomenters of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xinhai_Revolution" title="Xinhai Revolution">Xinhai Revolution</a> of 1911 sought to replace Qing rule with a republic and leaders like <a href="/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen" title="Sun Yat-sen">Sun Yat-sen</a> originally intended to return the capital to <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a>. After the Qing general <a href="/wiki/Yuan_Shikai" title="Yuan Shikai">Yuan Shikai</a> forced the abdication of the last Qing emperor and ensured the success of the revolution, the revolutionaries accepted him as president of the new <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republic of China</a>. Yuan maintained his capital at Beijing and quickly consolidated power, declaring himself emperor in 1915. His death less than a year later<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[60]</a></sup> left China under the control of the warlords commanding the regional armies. Following the success of the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Expedition_(1926%E2%80%931927)" title="Northern Expedition (1926–1927)">Northern Expedition</a>, the capital was formally moved to <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> in 1928. On 28 June the same year, Beijing's name was returned to Beiping (written at the time as "Peiping").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-columbia_encyclopaedia_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-columbia_encyclopaedia-19">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[61]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 7 July 1937, the 29th Army and the Japanese army in China exchanged fire at the <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo_Bridge" title="Marco Polo Bridge">Marco Polo Bridge</a> near the <a href="/wiki/Wanping_Fortress" title="Wanping Fortress">Wanping Fortress</a> southwest of the city. The <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo_Bridge_Incident" title="Marco Polo Bridge Incident">Marco Polo Bridge Incident</a> triggered the <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> as it is known in China. During the war,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-columbia_encyclopaedia_19-2"><a href="#cite_note-columbia_encyclopaedia-19">[18]</a></sup> Beijing fell to Japan on 29 July 1937<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[62]</a></sup> and was made the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_the_Republic_of_China_(1937%E2%80%931940)" title="Provisional Government of the Republic of China (1937–1940)">Provisional Government of the Republic of China</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Puppet_state" title="Puppet state">puppet state</a> that ruled the ethnic-Chinese portions of Japanese-occupied <a href="/wiki/North_China" title="North China">northern China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[63]</a></sup> This government was later merged into the larger <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reorganized_National_Government_of_China" title="Reorganized National Government of China">Wang Jingwei government</a> based in Nanjing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="People.27s_Republic_of_China"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="People's_Republic_of_China">People's Republic of China</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: People's Republic of China">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PRCFounding.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/PRCFounding.jpg/220px-PRCFounding.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/PRCFounding.jpg/330px-PRCFounding.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/PRCFounding.jpg/440px-PRCFounding.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PRCFounding.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> proclaiming the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949</div></div></div>
<p>In the final phases of the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People's Liberation Army">People's Liberation Army</a> seized control of the city peacefully on 31 January 1949 in the course of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pingjin_Campaign" title="Pingjin Campaign">Pingjin Campaign</a>. On 1 October that year, <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> announced the creation of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="People's Republic of China">People's Republic of China</a> from atop <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tian%27anmen" title="Tian'anmen">Tian'anmen</a>. He restored the name of the city, as the new capital, to Beijing,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[65]</a></sup> a decision that had been reached by the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_People%27s_Political_Consultative_Conference" title="Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference">Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference</a> just a few days earlier.
</p><p>In the 1950s, the city began to expand beyond the old walled city and its surrounding neighborhoods, with heavy industries in <a href="/wiki/Shijingshan_District" title="Shijingshan District">the west</a> and residential neighborhoods in <a href="/wiki/Hepingli_Subdistrict,_Beijing" title="Hepingli Subdistrict, Beijing">the north</a>. Many areas of the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_city_fortifications" title="Beijing city fortifications">Beijing city wall</a> were torn down in the 1960s to make way for the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Subway" title="Beijing Subway">Beijing Subway</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2nd_Ring_Road" title="2nd Ring Road">2nd Ring Road</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Olympics_2008.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="508" data-file-width="699" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Beijing_Olympics_2008.jpg/220px-Beijing_Olympics_2008.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Beijing_Olympics_2008.jpg/330px-Beijing_Olympics_2008.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Beijing_Olympics_2008.jpg/440px-Beijing_Olympics_2008.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Olympics_2008.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A scene from the opening ceremonies of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympic_Games" title="2008 Summer Olympic Games">2008 Summer Olympic Games</a></div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a> from 1966 to 1976, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red_Guard_(China)" title="Red Guard (China)">Red Guard</a> movement began in Beijing and the city's government fell victim to one of the first purges. By the autumn of 1966, all city schools were shut down and over a million Red Guards from across the country gathered in Beijing for eight rallies in Tian'anmen Square with Mao.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[66]</a></sup> In April 1976, a large public gathering of Beijing residents against the <a href="/wiki/Gang_of_Four" title="Gang of Four">Gang of Four</a> and the Cultural Revolution in Tiananmen Square <a href="/wiki/1976_Tiananmen_Incident" title="1976 Tiananmen Incident">was forcefully suppressed</a>. In October 1976, the Gang was arrested in <a href="/wiki/Zhongnanhai" title="Zhongnanhai">Zhongnanhai</a> and the Cultural Revolution came to an end. In December 1978, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Third_Plenary_Session_of_the_11th_CPC_Central_Committee" title="Third Plenary Session of the 11th CPC Central Committee">Third Plenum of the 11th Party Congress</a> in Beijing under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping" title="Deng Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a> reversed the verdicts against victims of the Cultural Revolution and instituted the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform" title="Chinese economic reform">"policy of reform and opening up."</a>
</p><p>Since the early 1980s, the urban area of Beijing has expanded greatly with the completion of the 2nd Ring Road in 1981 and the subsequent addition of the <a href="/wiki/3rd_Ring_Road_(Beijing)" title="3rd Ring Road (Beijing)">3rd</a>, <a href="/wiki/4th_Ring_Road" title="4th Ring Road">4th</a>, <a href="/wiki/5th_Ring_Road" title="5th Ring Road">5th</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/6th_Ring_Road" title="6th Ring Road">6th Ring Roads</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[68]</a></sup> According to one 2005 newspaper report, the size of newly developed Beijing was one-and-a-half times larger than before.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[69]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wangfujing" title="Wangfujing">Wangfujing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xidan" title="Xidan">Xidan</a> have developed into flourishing shopping districts,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[70]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Zhongguancun" title="Zhongguancun">Zhongguancun</a> has become a major center of electronics in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[71]</a></sup> In recent years, the expansion of Beijing has also brought to the forefront some problems of urbanization, such as <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">heavy traffic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution" title="Air pollution">poor air quality</a>, the loss of historic neighborhoods, and a significant influx of migrant workers from less-developed <a href="/wiki/Rural_area" title="Rural area">rural areas</a> of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[72]</a></sup> Beijing has also been the location of many significant events in recent Chinese history, principally the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989" title="Tiananmen Square protests of 1989">Tiananmen Square protests of 1989</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_News_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News-74">[73]</a></sup> The city has also hosted major international events, including the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2015_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2015 World Championships in Athletics">2015 World Championships in Athletics</a>, and was chosen to host the <a href="/wiki/2022_Winter_Olympics" title="2022 Winter Olympics">2022 Winter Olympics</a>, making it the first city to ever host both Winter and Summer Olympics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Geography">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Beijing" title="Geography of Beijing">Geography of Beijing</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Large_Beijing_Landsat.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Large_Beijing_Landsat.jpg/220px-Large_Beijing_Landsat.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Large_Beijing_Landsat.jpg/330px-Large_Beijing_Landsat.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Large_Beijing_Landsat.jpg/440px-Large_Beijing_Landsat.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Large_Beijing_Landsat.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Landsat_7" title="Landsat 7">Landsat 7</a> satellite image of Beijing Municipality with the surrounding mountains in dark brown</div></div></div>
<p>Beijing is situated at the northern tip of the roughly triangular <a href="/wiki/North_China_Plain" title="North China Plain">North China Plain</a>, which opens to the south and east of the city. Mountains to the north, northwest and west shield the city and northern China's agricultural heartland from the encroaching desert steppes. The northwestern part of the municipality, especially <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yanqing_County" title="Yanqing County">Yanqing County</a> and <a href="/wiki/Huairou_District" title="Huairou District">Huairou District</a>, are dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Jundu_Mountains" title="Jundu Mountains">Jundu Mountains</a>, while the western part is framed by <i>Xishan</i> or the <a href="/wiki/Western_Hills" title="Western Hills">Western Hills</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Great_Wall_of_China" title="Great Wall of China">Great Wall of China</a> across the northern part of Beijing Municipality was built on the rugged topography to defend against nomadic incursions from the steppes. <a href="/wiki/Mount_Ling_(Beijing)" title="Mount Ling (Beijing)">Mount Dongling</a>, in the Western Hills and on the border with <a href="/wiki/Hebei" title="Hebei">Hebei</a>, is the municipality's highest point, with an altitude of 2,303 metres (7,556 ft).
</p><p>Major rivers flowing through the municipality, including the <a href="/wiki/Chaobai_River" title="Chaobai River">Chaobai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yongding_River" title="Yongding River">Yongding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juma_River_(China)" title="Juma River (China)">Juma</a>, are all tributaries in the <a href="/wiki/Hai_River" title="Hai River">Hai River</a> system, and flow in a southeasterly direction. The Miyun Reservoir, on the upper reaches of the Chaobai River, is the largest reservoir within the municipality. Beijing is also the northern terminus of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Canal_of_China" title="Grand Canal of China">Grand Canal</a> to <a href="/wiki/Hangzhou" title="Hangzhou">Hangzhou</a>, which was built over 1,400 years ago as a transportation route, and the <a href="/wiki/South%E2%80%93North_Water_Transfer_Project" title="South–North Water Transfer Project">South–North Water Transfer Project</a>, constructed in the past decade to bring water from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze River</a> basin.
</p><p>The urban area of Beijing, on the plains in the south-central of the municipality with elevation of 40 to 60 metres (130–200 feet), occupies a relatively small but expanding portion of the municipality's area. The city spreads out in concentric <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ring_Roads_of_Beijing" title="Ring Roads of Beijing">ring roads</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Ring_Road_(Beijing)" title="Second Ring Road (Beijing)">Second Ring Road</a> traces the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_city_wall" title="Beijing city wall">old city walls</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sixth_Ring_Road" title="Sixth Ring Road">Sixth Ring Road</a> connects satellite towns in the surrounding suburbs. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tian%27anmen" title="Tian'anmen">Tian'anmen</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tian%27anmen_Square" title="Tian'anmen Square">Tian'anmen Square</a> are at the center of Beijing, directly to the south of the <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_City" title="Forbidden City">Forbidden City</a>, the former residence of the emperors of China. To the west of Tian'anmen is <a href="/wiki/Zhongnanhai" title="Zhongnanhai">Zhongnanhai</a>, the residence of China's current leaders. <a href="/wiki/Chang%27an_Avenue" title="Chang'an Avenue">Chang'an Avenue</a>, which cuts between Tiananmen and the Square, forms the city's main east–west axis.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cityscape">Cityscape</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Cityscape">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:808px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Forbidden_City_-_View_from_Coal_Hill.jpg" title="A panorama of the Forbidden City, viewed from the Jingshan Park"><img alt="" data-file-height="2046" data-file-width="4092" decoding="async" height="400" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/The_Forbidden_City_-_View_from_Coal_Hill.jpg/800px-The_Forbidden_City_-_View_from_Coal_Hill.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/The_Forbidden_City_-_View_from_Coal_Hill.jpg/1200px-The_Forbidden_City_-_View_from_Coal_Hill.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/The_Forbidden_City_-_View_from_Coal_Hill.jpg/1600px-The_Forbidden_City_-_View_from_Coal_Hill.jpg 2x" width="800"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Forbidden_City_-_View_from_Coal_Hill.jpg" title="File:The Forbidden City - View from Coal Hill.jpg"> </a></div>A panorama of the <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_City" title="Forbidden City">Forbidden City</a>, viewed from the <a href="/wiki/Jingshan_Park" title="Jingshan Park">Jingshan Park</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Architecture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Beijing" title="List of tallest buildings in Beijing">List of tallest buildings in Beijing</a></div>
<p>Three styles of architecture are predominant in urban Beijing. First, there is the traditional architecture of imperial China, perhaps best exemplified by the massive <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tian%27anmen" title="Tian'anmen">Tian'anmen</a> (Gate of Heavenly Peace), which remains the People's Republic of China's trademark edifice, the <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_City" title="Forbidden City">Forbidden City</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Ancestral_Temple" title="Imperial Ancestral Temple">Imperial Ancestral Temple</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Heaven" title="Temple of Heaven">Temple of Heaven</a>. Next, there is what is sometimes referred to as the "Sino-Sov" style, with structures tending to be boxy and sometimes poorly constructed, which were built between the 1950s and the 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[75]</a></sup> Finally, there are much more modern architectural forms, most noticeably in the area of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_CBD" title="Beijing CBD">Beijing CBD</a> in east Beijing such as the new <a href="/wiki/CCTV_Headquarters" title="CCTV Headquarters">CCTV Headquarters</a>, in addition to buildings in other locations around the city such as the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_National_Stadium" title="Beijing National Stadium">Beijing National Stadium</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Centre_for_the_Performing_Arts_(China)" title="National Centre for the Performing Arts (China)">National Center for the Performing Arts</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_before_communism,_1940-1948.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1556" data-file-width="2170" decoding="async" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Beijing_before_communism%2C_1940-1948.jpg/220px-Beijing_before_communism%2C_1940-1948.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Beijing_before_communism%2C_1940-1948.jpg/330px-Beijing_before_communism%2C_1940-1948.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Beijing_before_communism%2C_1940-1948.jpg/440px-Beijing_before_communism%2C_1940-1948.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_before_communism,_1940-1948.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>1940s <a href="/wiki/Nationalist_government" title="Nationalist government">Nationalist</a> Beijing with predominantly traditional architecture</div></div></div>
<p>Since 2007, buildings in Beijing have received the <a href="/wiki/CTBUH_Skyscraper_Award" title="CTBUH Skyscraper Award">CTBUH Skyscraper Award</a> for best overall tall building twice, for the <a href="/wiki/Linked_Hybrid" title="Linked Hybrid">Linked Hybrid</a> building in 2009 and the <a href="/wiki/CCTV_Headquarters" title="CCTV Headquarters">CCTV Headquarters</a> in 2013. The CTBUH Skyscraper award for best tall overall building is given to only one building around the world every year.
</p><p>In the early 21st century, Beijing has witnessed tremendous growth of new building constructions, exhibiting various modern styles from international designers, most pronounced in the CBD region. A mixture of both 1950s design and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Neofuturistic" title="Neofuturistic">neofuturistic</a> style of architecture can be seen at the <a href="/wiki/798_Art_Zone" title="798 Art Zone">798 Art Zone</a>, which mixes the old with the new. Beijing's tallest building is the 528-meter <a href="/wiki/China_Zun" title="China Zun">China Zun</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Doujiao_Hutong.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4912" data-file-width="7360" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Doujiao_Hutong.jpg/220px-Doujiao_Hutong.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Doujiao_Hutong.jpg/330px-Doujiao_Hutong.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Doujiao_Hutong.jpg/440px-Doujiao_Hutong.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Doujiao_Hutong.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The sign of Doujiao <a href="/wiki/Hutong" title="Hutong">Hutong</a>, one of the many traditional alleyways in the inner city</div></div></div>
<p>Beijing is famous for its <i><a href="/wiki/Siheyuan" title="Siheyuan">siheyuans</a></i>, a type of residence where a common courtyard is shared by the surrounding buildings. Among the more grand examples are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prince_Gong_Mansion" title="Prince Gong Mansion">Prince Gong Mansion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Former_Residence_of_Soong_Ching-ling_(Beijing)" title="Former Residence of Soong Ching-ling (Beijing)">Residence of Soong Ching-ling</a>. These courtyards are usually connected by alleys called <i><a href="/wiki/Hutong" title="Hutong">hutongs</a></i>. The <i>hutongs</i> are generally straight and run east to west so that doorways face north and south for good <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Feng_Shui" title="Feng Shui">Feng Shui</a>. They vary in width; some are so narrow only a few pedestrians can pass through at a time. Once ubiquitous in Beijing, <i>siheyuans</i> and <i>hutongs</i> are rapidly disappearing,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[76]</a></sup> as entire city blocks of <i>hutongs</i> are replaced by high-rise buildings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[77]</a></sup> Residents of the <i>hutongs</i> are entitled to live in the new buildings in apartments of at least the same size as their former residences. Many complain, however, that the traditional sense of community and street life of the <i>hutongs</i> cannot be replaced,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[78]</a></sup> and these properties are often government owned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Climate">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:442px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_average_annual_temperatures_1970_to_2019.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="2400" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Beijing_average_annual_temperatures_1970_to_2019.jpg/440px-Beijing_average_annual_temperatures_1970_to_2019.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Beijing_average_annual_temperatures_1970_to_2019.jpg/660px-Beijing_average_annual_temperatures_1970_to_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Beijing_average_annual_temperatures_1970_to_2019.jpg/880px-Beijing_average_annual_temperatures_1970_to_2019.jpg 2x" width="440"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_average_annual_temperatures_1970_to_2019.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Beijing average annual temperatures from 1970 to 2019 during summer (June, July, and August) and winter (December, January, and February). Weather station data from <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20211009101925/ftp://ftp.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/data/noaa/" rel="nofollow">ftp.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/data/noaa/</a>. For comparison the <a href="/wiki/Global_temperature_record" title="Global temperature record">Global Surface Temperature Anomaly</a> rose by approximately one degree over the same time period.</div></div></div><p> Beijing has a monsoon-influenced <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climate</a> (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen</a>: <i>Dwa</i>), characterized by hot, humid summers due to the East Asian <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a>, and brief but cold, dry winters that reflect the influence of the vast <a href="/wiki/Siberian_High" title="Siberian High">Siberian anticyclone</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-people's_daily_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-people's_daily-81">[80]</a></sup> Spring can bear witness to sandstorms blowing in from the <a href="/wiki/Gobi_Desert" title="Gobi Desert">Gobi Desert</a> across the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mongolian-Manchurian_grassland" title="Mongolian-Manchurian grassland">Mongolian steppe</a>, accompanied by rapidly warming, but generally dry, conditions. Autumn, similar to spring, is a season of transition and minimal precipitation. The monthly daily average temperature in January is −2.9 °C (26.8 °F), while in July it is 26.9 °C (80.4 °F). <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">Precipitation</a> averages around 570 mm (22 in) annually, with close to three-quarters of that total falling from June to August. With monthly percent possible sunshine ranging from 47% in July to 65% in January and February, the city receives 2,671 hours of bright sunshine annually. Extremes since 1951 have ranged from −27.4 °C (−17.3 °F) on 22 February 1966 to 41.9 °C (107.4 °F) on 24 July 1999 (unofficial record of 42.6 °C (108.7 °F) was set on 15 June 1942).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mherrera_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mherrera-83">[82]</a></sup>
</p><div>
<table class="wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="width:auto; text-align:center; line-height: 1.2em; margin:;">

</td></tr></tbody></table>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_issues">Environmental issues</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Environmental issues">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Beijing has a long history of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Environmental_problems" title="Environmental problems">environmental problems</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[87]</a></sup> Between 2000 and 2009 Beijing's urban extent quadrupled, which not only strongly increased the extent of anthropogenic emissions, but also changed the meteorological situation fundamentally, even if <a href="/wiki/Exhaust_gas" title="Exhaust gas">emissions</a> of human society are not included. For example, surface <a href="/wiki/Albedo" title="Albedo">albedo</a>, wind speed and <a href="/wiki/Humidity" title="Humidity">humidity</a> near the surface were decreased, whereas ground and near-surface <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Air_temperature" title="Air temperature">air temperatures</a>, vertical air dilution and <a href="/wiki/Ozone" title="Ozone">ozone</a> levels were increased.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[88]</a></sup> Because of the combined factors of urbanization and pollution caused by burning of <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil fuel</a>, Beijing is often affected by serious environmental problems, which lead to <a href="/wiki/Health" title="Health">health</a> issues of many inhabitants. In 2013 heavy <a href="/wiki/Smog" title="Smog">smog</a> struck Beijing and most parts of northern China, impacting a total of 600 million people. After this "pollution shock" <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution" title="Air pollution">air pollution</a> became an important economic and social concern in China. After that the government of Beijing announced measures to reduce air pollution, for example by lowering the share of coal from 24% in 2012 to 10% in 2017, while the national government ordered heavily polluting vehicles to be removed from 2015 to 2017 and increased its efforts to transition the energy system to clean sources.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Air_quality">Air quality</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Air quality">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Joint research between American and Chinese researchers in 2006 concluded that much of the city's pollution comes from surrounding cities and provinces. On average 35–60% of the <a href="/wiki/Ozone" title="Ozone">ozone</a> can be traced to sources outside the city. <a href="/wiki/Shandong" title="Shandong">Shandong</a> Province and <a href="/wiki/Tianjin" title="Tianjin">Tianjin</a> Municipality have a "significant influence on Beijing's air quality",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[90]</a></sup> partly due to the prevailing south/southeasterly flow during the summer and the mountains to the north and northwest.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_smog_comparison_August_2005.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Beijing_smog_comparison_August_2005.png/350px-Beijing_smog_comparison_August_2005.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Beijing_smog_comparison_August_2005.png/525px-Beijing_smog_comparison_August_2005.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Beijing_smog_comparison_August_2005.png/700px-Beijing_smog_comparison_August_2005.png 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_smog_comparison_August_2005.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Heavy air pollution has resulted in widespread smog. These photographs, taken in August 2005, show the variations in Beijing's air quality.</div></div></div>
<p>In preparation for the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> and to fulfill promises to clean up the city's air, nearly US$17 billion was spent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sundance_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-sundance-92">[91]</a></sup> Beijing implemented a number of air improvement schemes for the duration of the Games, including halting work at all construction sites, closing many factories in Beijing permanently, temporarily shutting industry in neighboring regions, closing some gas stations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[92]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Road_space_rationing_in_Beijing" title="Road space rationing in Beijing">cutting motor traffic by half by limiting drivers to odd or even days (based on their license plate numbers)</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[93]</a></sup> reducing bus and subway fares, opening new subway lines, and banning high-emission vehicles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-octpoll_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-octpoll-95">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-polluteban_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-polluteban-96">[95]</a></sup> The city further assembled 3,800 <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a>-powered buses, one of the largest fleets in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sundance_92-1"><a href="#cite_note-sundance-92">[91]</a></sup> Beijing became the first city in China to require the Chinese equivalent to the Euro 4 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emission_standard" title="Emission standard">emission standard</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>Coal burning accounts for about 40% of the <a href="/wiki/Particulates" title="Particulates">PM 2.5</a> in Beijing and is also the chief source of nitrogen and sulphur dioxide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MotherJones_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-MotherJones-98">[97]</a></sup> Since 2012, the city has been converting coal-fired <a href="/wiki/List_of_major_power_stations_in_Beijing" title="List of major power stations in Beijing">power stations</a> to burn natural gas<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNDaily20120308_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNDaily20120308-99">[98]</a></sup> and aims to cap annual coal consumption at 20 million tons. In 2011, the city burned 26.3 million tons of coal, 73% of which for heating and power generation and the remainder for industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNDaily20120308_99-1"><a href="#cite_note-CNDaily20120308-99">[98]</a></sup> Much of the city's air pollutants are emitted by neighboring regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MotherJones_98-1"><a href="#cite_note-MotherJones-98">[97]</a></sup> Coal consumption in neighboring Tianjin is expected to increase from 48 to 63 million tons from 2011 to 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SCMP20130205_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-SCMP20130205-100">[99]</a></sup> Hebei Province burned over 300 million tons of coal in 2011, more than all of Germany, of which only 30% were used for power generation and a considerable portion for steel and cement making.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[100]</a></sup> Power plants in the coal-mining regions of Shanxi, Inner Mongolia and Shaanxi, where coal consumption has tripled since 2000, and Shandong also contribute to air pollution in Beijing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MotherJones_98-2"><a href="#cite_note-MotherJones-98">[97]</a></sup> Shandong, Shanxi, Hebei and Inner Mongolia, respectively rank from first to fourth, among Chinese provinces by coal consumption.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SCMP20130205_100-1"><a href="#cite_note-SCMP20130205-100">[99]</a></sup> There were four major coal-fired power plants in the city to provide electricity as well as heating during the winter. The first one (Gaojing Thermal Power Plant) was shut down in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[101]</a></sup> Another two were shut in March 2015. The last one (Huaneng Thermal Power Plant) would be shut in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaDaily_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaDaily-103">[102]</a></sup> Between 2013 and 2017, the city planned to reduce 13 million tons of coal consumption and cap coal consumption to 15 million tons in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaDaily_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaDaily-103">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>The government sometimes uses <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cloud-seeding" title="Cloud-seeding">cloud-seeding</a> measures to increase the likelihood of rain showers in the region to clear the air prior to large events, such as prior to the 60th anniversary parade in 2009 as well as to combat drought conditions in the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[103]</a></sup> More recently, however, the government has increased its usage of such measures as closing factories temporarily and implementing greater restrictions for cars on the road, as in the case of "<a href="/wiki/APEC_blue" title="APEC blue">APEC blue</a>" and "parade blue," short periods during and immediately preceding the <a href="/wiki/APEC_China_2014" title="APEC China 2014">APEC China 2014</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2015_China_Victory_Day_Parade" title="2015 China Victory Day Parade">2015 China Victory Day Parade</a>, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[104]</a></sup> During and prior to these events, Beijing's air quality improved dramatically, only to fall back to unhealthy levels shortly after.
</p><p>Beijing air quality is often poor, especially in winter. In mid-January 2013, Beijing's air quality was measured on top of <a href="/wiki/Embassy_of_the_United_States,_Beijing" title="Embassy of the United States, Beijing">the city's US embassy</a> at a PM2.5 density of 755 micrograms per cubic meter, which is more than 75 times the safe level established by the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">WHO</a>, and went off the US Environmental Protection Agency's air quality index. It was widely reported, originally through a Twitter account, that the category was "crazy bad". This was later changed to "beyond index".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 8 and 9 December 2015 Beijing had its first <a href="/wiki/Smog" title="Smog">smog</a> alert which shut down a majority of the industry and other commercial businesses in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[106]</a></sup> Later in the month another smog "red alert" was issued.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abc-2nd-red_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-abc-2nd-red-108">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Beijing's environmental protection bureau's announcement in November 2016, starting from 2017 highly polluting old cars will be banned from being driven whenever Smog "red alerts" are issued in the city or neighboring regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>In recent years, there has been measurable reductions in pollutants after the "war on pollution" was declared in 2014, with Beijing seeing a 35% reduction in fine particulates in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[109]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Readings">Readings</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Readings">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Due to Beijing's high level of air pollution, there are various readings by different sources on the subject. Daily pollution readings at 27 monitoring stations around the city are reported on the website of the Beijing Environmental Protection Bureau (BJEPB).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[110]</a></sup> The American Embassy of Beijing also reports hourly <a href="/wiki/Particulates" title="Particulates">fine particulate (PM2.5)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ozone" title="Ozone">ozone</a> levels on Twitter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Demick_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-Demick-112">[111]</a></sup> Since the BJEPB and US Embassy measure different pollutants according to different criteria, the pollution levels and the impact to human health reported by the BJEPB are often lower than that reported by the US Embassy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Demick_112-1"><a href="#cite_note-Demick-112">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p>The smog is causing harm and danger to the population. The air pollution does directly result in significant impact on the mobility rate of cardiovascular disease and respiratory disease in Beijing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[112]</a></sup> Exposure to large concentrations of polluted air can cause respiratory and cardiovascular problems, emergency room visits, and even death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[113]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Dust_storms">Dust storms</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Dust storms">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Dust from the erosion of deserts in northern and northwestern China results in seasonal <a href="/wiki/Dust_storm" title="Dust storm">dust storms</a> that plague the city; the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Weather_Modification_Office" title="Beijing Weather Modification Office">Beijing Weather Modification Office</a> sometimes artificially induces rainfall to fight such storms and mitigate their effects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[114]</a></sup> In the first four months of 2006 alone, there were no fewer than eight such storms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[115]</a></sup> In April 2002, one dust storm alone dumped nearly 50,000 tons of dust onto the city before moving on to Japan and Korea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[116]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Government">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Beijing" title="Politics of Beijing">Politics of Beijing</a></div>
<p>The municipal government is regulated by the local <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party">Chinese Communist Party</a> (CCP), led by the Beijing <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party_Committee_Secretary" title="Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary">CCP Secretary</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh">中共北京市委书记</span>). The local CCP issues administrative orders, collects taxes, manages the economy, and directs a standing committee of the Municipal People's Congress in making policy decisions and overseeing the local government.
</p><p>Government officials include the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mayor_of_Beijing" title="Mayor of Beijing">mayor</a> (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>: <span lang="zh">市长</span>) and vice-mayor. Numerous bureaus focus on law, public security, and other affairs. Additionally, as the capital of China, Beijing houses all of the important national governmental and political institutions, including the <a href="/wiki/National_People%27s_Congress" title="National People's Congress">National People's Congress</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica_government_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-britannica_government-118">[117]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Administrative divisions">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a more comprehensive list, see <a href="/wiki/List_of_administrative_divisions_of_Beijing" title="List of administrative divisions of Beijing">List of administrative divisions of Beijing</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_township-level_divisions_of_Beijing" title="List of township-level divisions of Beijing">List of township-level divisions of Beijing</a>.</div>
<p>Beijing Municipality currently comprises 16 administrative <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/County-level_division" title="County-level division">county-level subdivisions</a> including 16 urban, suburban, and rural <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/District_of_China" title="District of China">districts</a>. On 1 July 2010, <a href="/wiki/Chongwen_District" title="Chongwen District">Chongwen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xuanwu_District,_Beijing" title="Xuanwu District, Beijing">Xuanwu</a> were merged into Dongcheng and Xicheng, respectively. On 13 November 2015 <a href="/wiki/Miyun_District" title="Miyun District">Miyun</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yanqing_District" title="Yanqing District">Yanqing</a> were upgraded to districts.
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="margin:1em auto 1em auto; width:90%; text-align:center">
