</li>
</ol></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Houhai_Lake_and_Drum_Tower_Beijing_2015_October.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2560" data-file-width="3840" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Houhai_Lake_and_Drum_Tower_Beijing_2015_October.jpg/220px-Houhai_Lake_and_Drum_Tower_Beijing_2015_October.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Houhai_Lake_and_Drum_Tower_Beijing_2015_October.jpg/330px-Houhai_Lake_and_Drum_Tower_Beijing_2015_October.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Houhai_Lake_and_Drum_Tower_Beijing_2015_October.jpg/440px-Houhai_Lake_and_Drum_Tower_Beijing_2015_October.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Houhai_Lake_and_Drum_Tower_Beijing_2015_October.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Houhai Lake and Drum Tower at <a href="/wiki/Shichahai" title="Shichahai">Shichahai</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Xicheng_District" title="Xicheng District">Xicheng District</a></div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Towns">Towns</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Towns">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_township-level_divisions_of_Beijing" title="List of township-level divisions of Beijing">List of township-level divisions of Beijing</a></div>
<p>Beijing's 16 county-level divisions (districts) are further subdivided into 273 lower third-level administrative units at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China#Township_level" title="Administrative divisions of the People's Republic of China">township level</a>: 119 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Town_of_China" title="Town of China">towns</a>, 24 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Townships_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Townships of the People's Republic of China">townships</a>, 5 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_township" title="Ethnic township">ethnic townships</a> and 125 <a href="/wiki/Subdistricts_of_China" title="Subdistricts of China">subdistricts</a>.
Towns within Beijing Municipality but outside the urban area include (but are not limited to):
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r998391716">.mw-parser-output .div-col{margin-top:0.3em;column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .div-col-small{font-size:90%}.mw-parser-output .div-col-rules{column-rule:1px solid #aaa}.mw-parser-output .div-col dl,.mw-parser-output .div-col ol,.mw-parser-output .div-col ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .div-col li,.mw-parser-output .div-col dd{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 22em;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Changping_District" title="Changping District">Changping</a> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">昌平</span></span></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Huairou" title="Huairou">Huairou</a> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">怀柔</span></span></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miyun" title="Miyun">Miyun</a> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">密云</span></span></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Liangxiang,_Beijing" title="Liangxiang, Beijing">Liangxiang</a> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">良乡</span></span></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Liulimiao" title="Liulimiao">Liulimiao</a> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">琉璃庙</span></span></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tongzhou_District,_Beijing" title="Tongzhou District, Beijing">Tongzhou</a> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">通州</span></span></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Yizhuang,_Beijing" title="Yizhuang, Beijing">Yizhuang</a> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">亦庄</span></span></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tiantongyuan" title="Tiantongyuan">Tiantongyuan</a> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">天通苑</span></span></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beiyuan,_Beijing" title="Beiyuan, Beijing">Beiyuan</a> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">北苑</span></span></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Xiaotangshan,_Beijing" title="Xiaotangshan, Beijing">Xiaotangshan</a> <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">小汤山</span></span></li></ul>
</div>
<p>Several place names in Beijing end with <i>mén</i> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">门</span></span>), meaning "gate", as they were the locations of gates in the former <a href="/wiki/Beijing_city_fortifications" title="Beijing city fortifications">Beijing city wall</a>. Other place names end in <i>cūn</i> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">村</span></span>), meaning "village", as they were originally villages outside the city wall.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Judiciary_and_procuracy">Judiciary and procuracy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Judiciary and procuracy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Judicial system of the People's Republic of China">judicial system</a> in Beijing consists of the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_People%27s_Court" title="Supreme People's Court">Supreme People's Court</a>, the highest court in the country, the Beijing Municipal High People's Court, the <a href="/wiki/High_people%27s_court" title="High people's court">high people's court</a> of the municipality, three <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intermediate_people%27s_courts" title="Intermediate people's courts">intermediate people's courts</a>, one intermediate <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Railway_Transport_Court_(People%27s_Republic_of_China)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Railway Transport Court (People's Republic of China) (page does not exist)">railway transport court</a>, 14 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Basic_people%27s_court" title="Basic people's court">basic people's court</a> (one for each of the municipality's districts and counties), and one basic railway transport court. The Beijing No. 1 Intermediate People's Court in Shijingshan oversees the basic courts of Haidian, Shijingshan, Mentougou, Changping and Yanqing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Xinhuacourts_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-Xinhuacourts-125">[123]</a></sup> The Beijing No. 2 Intermediate People's Court in Fengtai oversees the basic courts of Dongcheng, Xicheng, Fengtai, Fangshan and Daxing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Xinhuacourts_125-1"><a href="#cite_note-Xinhuacourts-125">[123]</a></sup> The Beijing No. 3 Intermediate People's Court in Laiguangying, is the newest of the three intermediate people's courts and opened on 21 August 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Xinhuacourts_125-2"><a href="#cite_note-Xinhuacourts-125">[123]</a></sup> It oversees the district courts of Chaoyang, Tongzhou, Shunyi, Huairou, Pinggu and Miyun.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Xinhuacourts_125-3"><a href="#cite_note-Xinhuacourts-125">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BJcourts_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-BJcourts-126">[124]</a></sup> Each court in Beijing has a corresponding <a href="/wiki/Supreme_People%27s_Procuratorate" title="Supreme People's Procuratorate">people's procuratorate</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Economy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Beijing" title="Economy of Beijing">Economy of Beijing</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Xidan.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="769" data-file-width="1026" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Xidan.jpg/220px-Xidan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Xidan.jpg/330px-Xidan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Xidan.jpg/440px-Xidan.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Xidan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Xidan" title="Xidan">Xidan</a> is one of the oldest and busiest shopping areas in Beijing.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Product_Exports_(2020).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="228" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Beijing_Product_Exports_%282020%29.svg/350px-Beijing_Product_Exports_%282020%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Beijing_Product_Exports_%282020%29.svg/525px-Beijing_Product_Exports_%282020%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Beijing_Product_Exports_%282020%29.svg/700px-Beijing_Product_Exports_%282020%29.svg.png 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Product_Exports_(2020).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Beijing products treemap, 2020</div></div></div>
<p>As of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Beijing's <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">nominal GDP</a> was US$458 billion (<a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">CN￥</a>3.0 trillion), about 3.45% of the country's GDP and ranked <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_administrative_divisions_by_GDP" title="List of Chinese administrative divisions by GDP">12th</a> among <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_China" title="Administrative divisions of China">province-level administrative units</a>; its nominal GDP per capita was US$21,261 (CN￥140,748) and ranked the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_administrative_divisions_by_GDP_per_capita" title="List of Chinese administrative divisions by GDP per capita">1st</a> in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SNA2008_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-SNA2008-127">[125]</a></sup>  As of 2021, Beijing's <a href="/wiki/Gross_regional_product" title="Gross regional product">gross regional products</a> was <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">CN￥</a>4 trillion ($965 billion in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GDP_PPP" title="GDP PPP">GDP PPP</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[126]</a></sup> ranking among the 10th largest metropolitan economies in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[127]</a></sup> Beijing's nominal GDP is projected to reach US$1.1 trillion in 2035, ranking among the world's top 10 largest cities (together with <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guangzhou" title="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">Shenzhen</a> in China) according to a study by <a href="/wiki/Oxford_Economic_Papers" title="Oxford Economic Papers">Oxford Economics</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[128]</a></sup> and its nominal GDP per capita will reach US$45,000 in 2030.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[129]</a></sup>
</p><p>Due to the concentration of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_State-owned_enterprises_in_China" title="List of State-owned enterprises in China">state owned enterprises</a> in the national capital, Beijing in 2013 had more <a href="/wiki/Fortune_Global_500" title="Fortune Global 500">Fortune Global 500</a> Company headquarters than any other city in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JLL_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-JLL-132">[130]</a></sup> As of August 2022, Beijing has 54 <a href="/wiki/Fortune_Global_500" title="Fortune Global 500">Fortune Global 500</a> companies, more than Japan (47), the third-place country after China (145) and the United States (124).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[131]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[132]</a></sup> Beijing has also been described as the "<a href="/wiki/Billionaire" title="Billionaire">billionaire</a> capital of the world".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-135">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-136">[134]</a></sup> In 2020, Beijing is the 5th wealthiest city in the world, with a total wealth amounts to $2 trillion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[135]</a></sup> Beijing is classified as an Alpha+ (global first-tier) city by the <a href="/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network" title="Globalization and World Cities Research Network">Globalization and World Cities Research Network</a>, indicating its influence in the region and worldwide and making it one of the world's Top 10 major cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup> In the 2021 <a href="/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index" title="Global Financial Centres Index">Global Financial Centres Index</a>, Beijing was ranked as having the sixth-most competitive financial center in the world and fourth-most competitive in the whole Asia &amp; Oceania region (behind Shanghai, Hong Kong and Singapore).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GFCI2_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-GFCI2-139">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2021, Beijing was ranked first globally in terms of "<i>Global City Competitiveness</i>" in the <i>2020–2021 Global Urban Competitiveness Report</i> jointly released by the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Academy_of_Social_Sciences" title="Chinese Academy of Social Sciences">Chinese Academy of Social Sciences</a> (CASS) and the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Human_Settlements_Programme" title="United Nations Human Settlements Programme">United Nations Programme for Human Settlements</a> (UN-Habitat).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[138]</a></sup> Beijing is also a large hub of the Chinese and global technology industry and ranked as having the strongest global startup ecosystem in the whole of Asia-Oceania region, ranking 3rd globally by the Global Startup Ecosystem Index.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right;">
