</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sector_composition">Sector composition</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Sector composition">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sanlitun_at_dusk.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Sanlitun_at_dusk.jpg/220px-Sanlitun_at_dusk.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Sanlitun_at_dusk.jpg/330px-Sanlitun_at_dusk.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Sanlitun_at_dusk.jpg/440px-Sanlitun_at_dusk.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sanlitun_at_dusk.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Taikoo_Li_Sanlitun" title="Taikoo Li Sanlitun">Taikoo Li Sanlitun</a> shopping arcade is a destination for locals and visitors.</div></div></div>
<p>The city has a <a href="/wiki/Post-industrial_economy" title="Post-industrial economy">post-industrial economy</a> that is dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">tertiary sector</a> (services), which generated 76.9% of output, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Secondary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Secondary sector of the economy">secondary sector</a> (manufacturing, construction) at 22.2% and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Primary_sector" title="Primary sector">primary sector</a> (agriculture, mining) at 0.8%.
</p><p>The services sector is broadly diversified with professional services, wholesale and retail, information technology, commercial real estate, scientific research, and residential real estate each contributing at least 6% to the city's economy in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup>
</p><p>The single largest sub-sector remains industry, whose share of overall output has shrunk to 18.1% in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-1"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup> The mix of industrial output has changed significantly since 2010 when the city announced that 140 highly-polluting, energy and water resource intensive enterprises would be relocated from the city in five years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[142]</a></sup> The relocation of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shougang_Corporation" title="Shougang Corporation">Capital Steel</a> to neighboring Hebei province had begun in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[144]</a></sup> In 2013, output of automobiles, aerospace products, semiconductors, pharmaceuticals, and food processing all increased.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-2"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the farmland around Beijing, vegetables and fruits have displaced grain as the primary crops under cultivation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-3"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup> In 2013, the tonnage of vegetable, edible fungus and fruit harvested was over three times that of grain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-4"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup> In 2013, overall acreage under cultivation shrank along with most categories of produce as more land was reforested for environmental reasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-5"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_zones">Economic zones</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Economic zones">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a more comprehensive list, see <a href="/wiki/List_of_economic_and_technological_development_zones_in_Beijing" title="List of economic and technological development zones in Beijing">List of economic and technological development zones in Beijing</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Parkview_Green_and_CBD_skyline_(20210927131419).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4453" data-file-width="6679" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Parkview_Green_and_CBD_skyline_%2820210927131419%29.jpg/220px-Parkview_Green_and_CBD_skyline_%2820210927131419%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Parkview_Green_and_CBD_skyline_%2820210927131419%29.jpg/330px-Parkview_Green_and_CBD_skyline_%2820210927131419%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Parkview_Green_and_CBD_skyline_%2820210927131419%29.jpg/440px-Parkview_Green_and_CBD_skyline_%2820210927131419%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Parkview_Green_and_CBD_skyline_(20210927131419).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The skyline of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_CBD" title="Beijing CBD">Beijing CBD</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Zhongguancun_from_Huangzhuang_North_Footbridge_(20201214122926).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2688" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Zhongguancun_from_Huangzhuang_North_Footbridge_%2820201214122926%29.jpg/220px-Zhongguancun_from_Huangzhuang_North_Footbridge_%2820201214122926%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Zhongguancun_from_Huangzhuang_North_Footbridge_%2820201214122926%29.jpg/330px-Zhongguancun_from_Huangzhuang_North_Footbridge_%2820201214122926%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Zhongguancun_from_Huangzhuang_North_Footbridge_%2820201214122926%29.jpg/440px-Zhongguancun_from_Huangzhuang_North_Footbridge_%2820201214122926%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Zhongguancun_from_Huangzhuang_North_Footbridge_(20201214122926).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Zhongguancun" title="Zhongguancun">Zhongguancun</a> is a technology hub in <a href="/wiki/Haidian_District" title="Haidian District">Haidian District</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In 2006, the city government identified six high-end economic output zones around Beijing as the primary engines for local economic growth. In 2012, the six zones produced 43.3% of the city's GDP, up from 36.5% in 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[146]</a></sup>
The six zones are:
</p>
<ol><li><a href="/wiki/Zhongguancun" title="Zhongguancun">Zhongguancun</a>, China's silicon village in Haidian District northwest of the city, is home to both established and start-up tech companies. In the first two quarters of 2014, 9,895 companies registered in the six zones, among which 6,150 were based in Zhongguancun.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[147]</a></sup> Zhongguancun is also the center of <a href="/wiki/Beijing-Tianjin-Shijiazhuang_Hi-Tech_Industrial_Belt" title="Beijing-Tianjin-Shijiazhuang Hi-Tech Industrial Belt">Beijing-Tianjin-Shijiazhuang Hi-Tech Industrial Belt</a>.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Financial_Street" title="Beijing Financial Street">Beijing Financial Street</a>, in Xicheng District on the west side of the city between Fuxingmen and Fuchengmen, is lined with headquarters of large state banks and insurance companies. The country's financial regulatory agencies including the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Bank_of_China" title="People's Bank of China">central bank</a>, <a href="/wiki/China_Banking_Regulatory_Commission" title="China Banking Regulatory Commission">bank regulator</a>, <a href="/wiki/China_Securities_Regulatory_Commission" title="China Securities Regulatory Commission">securities regulator</a>, and <a href="/wiki/State_Administration_of_Foreign_Exchange" title="State Administration of Foreign Exchange">foreign exchange authority</a> are located in the neighborhood.</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_CBD" title="Beijing CBD">Beijing Central Business District (CBD)</a>, is actually located to the east of downtown, near the embassies along the eastern Third Ring Road between Jianguomenwai and Chaoyangmenwai. The CBD is home to most of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Beijing" title="List of tallest buildings in Beijing">city's skyscraper office buildings</a>. Most of the city's foreign companies and professional service firms are based in the CBD.</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_Economic_and_Technological_Development_Area" title="Beijing Economic and Technological Development Area">Beijing Economic and Technological Development Area</a>, better known as <a href="/wiki/Yizhuang,_Beijing" title="Yizhuang, Beijing">Yizhuang</a>, is an industrial park the straddles the southern Fifth Ring Road in Daxing District. It has attracted pharmaceutical, information technology, and materials engineering companies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-social_economic_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-social_economic-150">[148]</a></sup></li>
<li>Beijing Airport Economic Zone was created in 1993 and surrounds the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Capital_International_Airport" title="Beijing Capital International Airport">Beijing Capital International Airport</a> in Shunyi District northeast of the city. In addition to logistics, airline services, and trading firms, this zone is also home to Beijing's automobile assembly plants.</li>
<li>Beijing Olympic Center Zone surrounds the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Green" title="Olympic Green">Olympic Green</a> due north of downtown and is developing into an entertainment, sports, tourism and business convention center.</li></ol>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shijingshan" title="Shijingshan">Shijingshan</a>, on the western outskirts of the city, is a traditional heavy industrial base for steel-making.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[149]</a></sup> Chemical plants are concentrated in the far eastern suburbs.
</p><p>Less legitimate enterprises also exist. Urban Beijing is known for being a center of <a href="/wiki/Copyright_infringement" title="Copyright infringement">infringed</a> goods; anything from the latest designer clothing to DVDs can be found in markets all over the city, often marketed to expatriates and international visitors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[150]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Demographics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Beijing" title="Demographics of Beijing">Demographics of Beijing</a></div>
<table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-top-width:0;border-spacing: 0;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 0.5em;"><caption style="border-top:1px #aaa solid;border-left:1px #aaa solid;border-right:1px #aaa solid;background-color:lavender;padding:0.25em;font-weight:bold">Historical population</caption><tbody><tr style="font-size:95%"><th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;width:3em">Year</th><th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px 2px;text-align:right"><abbr title="Population">Pop.</abbr></th><th style="border-bottom:1px solid black;padding:1px;text-align:right"><abbr title="Per annum growth rate">±% p.a.</abbr></th></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1953</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">2,768,149</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">—    </td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1964</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">7,568,495</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+9.57%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1982</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">9,230,687</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.11%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">1990</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">10,819,407</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+2.00%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">2000</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">13,569,194</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">+2.29%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2010</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">19,612,368</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+3.75%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2013</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">21,150,000</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+2.55%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px">2014<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bulletin2014_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-bulletin2014-153">[151]</a></sup></th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">21,516,000</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.73%</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left">Population size may be affected by changes on administrative divisions.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In 2013, Beijing had a total population of 21.148 million within the municipality, of which 18.251 million resided in urban districts or suburban townships and 2.897 million lived in rural villages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-6"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup> The encompassing <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_area" title="Metropolitan area">metropolitan area</a> was estimated by the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> (Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development) to have, as of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, a population of 24.9 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd2015_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-oecd2015-155">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>Within China, the city ranked <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_China_by_population" title="List of cities in China by population">second in urban population</a> after Shanghai and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct-controlled_municipalities_of_China" title="Direct-controlled municipalities of China">third in municipal population</a> after Shanghai and Chongqing. Beijing also ranks among the most populous cities in the world, a distinction the city has held for much of the past 800 years, especially during the 15th to early 19th centuries when it was <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_throughout_history" title="List of largest cities throughout history">the largest city in the world</a>.
</p><p>About 13 million of the city's residents in 2013 had local <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hukou_system" title="Hukou system"><i>hukou</i> permits</a>, which entitles them to permanent residence in Beijing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-7"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup> The remaining 8 million residents had <i>hukou</i> permits elsewhere and were not eligible to receive some social benefits provided by the Beijing municipal government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-8"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup>
</p><p>The population increased in 2013 by 455,000 or about 7% from the previous year and continued a decade-long trend of rapid growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-9"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup> The total population in 2004 was 14.213 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2004pop_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-2004pop-156">[154]</a></sup> The population gains are driven largely by migration. The population's <a href="/wiki/Rate_of_natural_increase" title="Rate of natural increase">rate of natural increase</a> in 2013 was a mere 0.441%, based on a <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a> of 8.93 and a <a href="/wiki/Mortality_rate" title="Mortality rate">mortality rate</a> of 4.52.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-10"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Human_sex_ratio" title="Human sex ratio">gender balance</a> was 51.6% males and 48.4% females.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-11"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup>
</p><p>Working age people account for nearly 80% of the population. Compared to 2004, residents age 0–14 as a proportion of the population dropped from 9.96% to 9.5% in 2013 and residents over the age of 65 declined from 11.12% to 9.2%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013_Beijing_Stats_143-12"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Beijing_Stats-143">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2004pop_156-1"><a href="#cite_note-2004pop-156">[154]</a></sup> From 2000 to 2010, the percentage of city residents with at least some college education nearly doubled from 16.8% to 31.5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010census_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-2010census-157">[155]</a></sup> About 22.2% have some high school education and 31% had reached middle school.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010census_157-1"><a href="#cite_note-2010census-157">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the 2010 census, nearly 96% of Beijing's population are ethnic <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han Chinese</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010census_157-2"><a href="#cite_note-2010census-157">[155]</a></sup> Of the 800,000 ethnic minority population living in the capital, <a href="/wiki/Manchu_people" title="Manchu people">Manchu</a> (336,000), <a href="/wiki/Hui_people_in_Beijing" title="Hui people in Beijing">Hui</a> (249,000), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Korean_people_in_Beijing" title="Korean people in Beijing">Korean</a> (77,000), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mongol" title="Mongol">Mongol</a> (37,000) and <a href="/wiki/Tujia_people" title="Tujia people">Tujia</a> (24,000) constitute the five largest groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010minorities_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-2010minorities-158">[156]</a></sup> In addition, there were 8,045 Hong Kong residents, 500 Macau residents, and 7,772 Taiwan residents along with 91,128 registered foreigners living in Beijing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010census_157-3"><a href="#cite_note-2010census-157">[155]</a></sup> A study by the Beijing Academy of Sciences estimates that in 2010 there were on average 200,000 foreigners living in Beijing on any given day including students, business travellers and tourists that are not counted as registered residents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2017 the Chinese government implemented population controls for Beijing and Shanghai to fight what it called the "big city disease" which includes congestion, pollution, and shortages of education and health care services. From this policy, Beijing's population declined by 20,000 from 2016 to 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cap_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-cap-160">[158]</a></sup> Some low-income people are being forcibly removed from the city as both legal and illegal housing is being demolished in some high-density residential neighborhoods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cap_160-1"><a href="#cite_note-cap-160">[158]</a></sup> The population is being redistributed to <a href="/wiki/Jing-Jin-Ji" title="Jing-Jin-Ji">Jing-Jin-Ji</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xiong%27an_New_Area" title="Xiong'an New Area">Xiong'an New Area</a>, the transfer to the latter expected to include 300,000-500,000 people working in government research, universities, and corporate headquarters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education_and_research">Education and research</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Education and research">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Beijing" title="Education in Beijing">Education in Beijing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Education_in_China" title="Education in China">Education in China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_China" title="Higher education in China">Higher education in China</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_and_colleges_in_Beijing" title="List of universities and colleges in Beijing">List of universities and colleges in Beijing</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_China" title="List of universities in China">List of universities in China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Double_First_Class_University_Plan" title="Double First Class University Plan">Double First Class University Plan</a></div><p>Beijing is a world leading center for scientific and technological innovation and has been ranked the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_scientific_output" title="List of cities by scientific output">No.1</a> city in the world with the largest scientific research output, as tracked by the <a href="/wiki/Nature_Index" title="Nature Index">Nature Index</a> since 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:10_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-:10-34">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:7_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-:7-163">[161]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:9_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-:9-35">[34]</a></sup> The city is also leading the world with the highest share of articles published in the fields of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Physical_Sciences" title="Physical Sciences">physical sciences</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chemistry" title="Chemistry">chemistry</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Earth_and_Environmental_Sciences" title="Earth and Environmental Sciences">earth &amp; environmental sciences</a>, especially in the United Nations'17 <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_Development_Goals" title="Sustainable Development Goals">Sustainable Development Goals</a> (SDGs) related output.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[162]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beijing has over <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_and_colleges_in_Beijing" title="List of universities and colleges in Beijing">90 public colleges and universities</a>, which is the largest urban <a href="/wiki/Public_university" title="Public university">public university</a> system in Asia and the first city in China with most higher education institutions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beijing's_Universities_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beijing's_Universities-168">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:13_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-:13-169">[167]</a></sup> and it is home to the two best universities (<a href="/wiki/Tsinghua_University" title="Tsinghua University">Tsinghua</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peking_University" title="Peking University">Peking</a>) in the whole of Asia-Oceania region and emerging countries with its shared rankings at 16th place in the world by the 2022 <a href="/wiki/Times_Higher_Education_World_University_Rankings" title="Times Higher Education World University Rankings">Times Higher Education World University Rankings</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:6_32-1"><a href="#cite_note-:6-32">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:8_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-:8-33">[32]</a></sup> Both are members of the <a href="/wiki/C9_League" title="C9 League">C9 League</a>, an alliance of elite Chinese universities offering comprehensive and leading education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>A number of Beijing's <a href="/wiki/Rankings_of_universities_in_China" title="Rankings of universities in China">most prestigious universities</a> consistently rank among the best in the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific" title="Asia-Pacific">Asia-Pacific</a> and the world, including <a href="/wiki/Peking_University" title="Peking University">Peking University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tsinghua_University" title="Tsinghua University">Tsinghua University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renmin_University_of_China" title="Renmin University of China">Renmin University of China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Normal_University" title="Beijing Normal University">Beijing Normal University</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Chinese_Academy_of_Sciences" title="University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences">University of Chinese Academy of Sciences</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beihang_University" title="Beihang University">Beihang University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Institute_of_Technology" title="Beijing Institute of Technology">Beijing Institute of Technology</a>, <a href="/wiki/China_Agricultural_University" title="China Agricultural University">China Agricultural University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Minzu_University_of_China" title="Minzu University of China">Minzu University of China</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Science_and_Technology_Beijing" title="University of Science and Technology Beijing">University of Science and Technology Beijing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beijing_University_of_Chemical_Technology" title="Beijing University of Chemical Technology">Beijing University of Chemical Technology</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_International_Business_and_Economics_(Beijing)" title="University of International Business and Economics (Beijing)">University of International Business and Economics</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Chinese_Academy_of_Social_Sciences" title="University of Chinese Academy of Social Sciences">University of Chinese Academy of Social Sciences</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_University_of_Finance_and_Economics" title="Central University of Finance and Economics">Central University of Finance and Economics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_30-1"><a href="#cite_note-:4-30">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_31-1"><a href="#cite_note-:5-31">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:11_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-:11-172">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[171]</a></sup> These universities were selected as "<a href="/wiki/Project_985" title="Project 985">985 universities</a>" or "<a href="/wiki/Project_211" title="Project 211">211 universities</a>" by the Chinese government in order to build world-class universities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>
Some of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_and_colleges_in_Beijing" title="List of universities and colleges in Beijing">national key universities</a> in Beijing are:<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></p><div class="div-col">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Forestry_University" title="Beijing Forestry University">Beijing Forestry University</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Jiaotong_University" title="Beijing Jiaotong University">Beijing Jiaotong University</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_University_of_Technology" title="Beijing University of Technology">Beijing University of Technology</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_University_of_Chinese_Medicine" title="Beijing University of Chinese Medicine">Beijing University of Chinese Medicine</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_University_of_Posts_and_Telecommunications" title="Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications">Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Electronic_Science_and_Technology_Institute" title="Beijing Electronic Science and Technology Institute">Beijing Electronic Science and Technology Institute</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Foreign_Studies_University" title="Beijing Foreign Studies University">Beijing Foreign Studies University</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Language_and_Culture_University" title="Beijing Language and Culture University">Beijing Language and Culture University</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Sport_University" title="Beijing Sport University">Beijing Sport University</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Conservatory_of_Music" title="Central Conservatory of Music">Central Conservatory of Music</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Academy_of_Fine_Arts" title="Central Academy of Fine Arts">Central Academy of Fine Arts</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Academy_of_Drama" title="Central Academy of Drama">Central Academy of Drama</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/China_University_of_Geosciences_(Beijing)" title="China University of Geosciences (Beijing)">China University of Geosciences (Beijing)</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/China_University_of_Petroleum_(Beijing)" title="China University of Petroleum (Beijing)">China University of Petroleum (Beijing)</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/China_University_of_Mining_and_Technology_(Beijing)" title="China University of Mining and Technology (Beijing)">China University of Mining and Technology (Beijing)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/China_University_of_Political_Science_and_Law" title="China University of Political Science and Law">China University of Political Science and Law</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/China_Foreign_Affairs_University" title="China Foreign Affairs University">China Foreign Affairs University</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_People%27s_Public_Security_University" title="Chinese People's Public Security University">Chinese People's Public Security University</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/China_Women%27s_University" title="China Women's University">China Women's University</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/China_Youth_University_for_Political_Sciences" title="China Youth University for Political Sciences">China Youth University for Political Sciences</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/China_Institute_of_Industrial_Relations" title="China Institute of Industrial Relations">China Institute of Industrial Relations</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Communication_University_of_China" title="Communication University of China">Communication University of China</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/North_China_Electric_Power_University" title="North China Electric Power University">North China Electric Power University</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peking_Union_Medical_College" title="Peking Union Medical College">Peking Union Medical College</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/University_of_International_Relations" title="University of International Relations">University of International Relations</a></li></ul></div><p>
Beijing is also home to several religious institutions, Some of them are listed as follows:<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></p><div class="div-col">
<ul><li>China Islamic Institute (中国伊斯兰教经学院)</li>
<li>Beijing Islamic Institute (北京伊斯蘭教經學院)</li>
<li>The Buddhist Academy of China (中国佛学院)</li>
<li>High-level Tibetan Buddhism College of China (中国藏语系高级佛学院)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/National_Seminary_of_Catholic_Church_in_China" title="National Seminary of Catholic Church in China">National Seminary of Catholic Church in China</a> (中国天主教神哲学院)</li></ul>
</div>
<p>The city is a seat of the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Chinese Academy of Sciences">Chinese Academy of Sciences</a>, which has been consistently ranked the No.1 research institute in the world by <i><a href="/wiki/Nature_Index" title="Nature Index">Nature Index</a></i> since the list's inception in 2016, by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nature_Research" title="Nature Research">Nature Research</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[175]</a></sup> Beijing is also a site of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Academy_of_Engineering" title="Chinese Academy of Engineering">Chinese Academy of Engineering</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Academy_of_Social_Sciences" title="Chinese Academy of Social Sciences">Chinese Academy of Social Sciences</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Natural_Science_Foundation_of_China" title="National Natural Science Foundation of China">National Natural Science Foundation of China</a>.
</p><p>The city's <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education" title="Compulsory education">compulsory education</a> system is among the best in the world: in 2018, 15-year-old students from Beijing (together with <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zhejiang" title="Zhejiang">Zhejiang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jiangsu" title="Jiangsu">Jiangsu</a>) outperformed all of the other 78 participating countries in all categories (math, reading, and science) in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Program_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Program for International Student Assessment">Program for International Student Assessment</a>, a worldwide study of academic performance conducted by the OECD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PISA2018_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-PISA2018-178">[176]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ancient_Beijing_observatory_10.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Ancient_Beijing_observatory_10.jpg/220px-Ancient_Beijing_observatory_10.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Ancient_Beijing_observatory_10.jpg/330px-Ancient_Beijing_observatory_10.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Ancient_Beijing_observatory_10.jpg/440px-Ancient_Beijing_observatory_10.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ancient_Beijing_observatory_10.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Ancient_Observatory" title="Beijing Ancient Observatory">Beijing Ancient Observatory</a></div></div></div>
<p>People native to urban Beijing speak the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_dialect" title="Beijing dialect">Beijing dialect</a>, which belongs to the Mandarin subdivision of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_spoken_language" title="Chinese spoken language">spoken Chinese</a>. This speech is the basis for <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Putonghua" title="Putonghua">putonghua</a></i>, the standard spoken language used in mainland China and <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>, and one of the four official languages of <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>. Rural areas of Beijing Municipality have <a href="/wiki/Jilu_Mandarin" title="Jilu Mandarin">their own dialects</a> akin to those of Hebei province, which surrounds Beijing Municipality.
</p><p>Beijing or <a href="/wiki/Peking_opera" title="Peking opera">Peking opera</a> is a traditional form of Chinese theater well known throughout the nation. Commonly lauded as one of the highest achievements of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">Chinese culture</a>, Beijing opera is performed through a combination of song, spoken dialogue, and codified action sequences involving gestures, movement, fighting and acrobatics. Much of Beijing opera is carried out in an archaic stage dialect quite different from Modern Standard Chinese and from the modern Beijing dialect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[177]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Beijing_cuisine" title="Beijing cuisine">Beijing cuisine</a> is the local style of cooking. <a href="/wiki/Peking_duck" title="Peking duck">Peking duck</a> is perhaps the best known dish. <a href="/wiki/Fuling_jiabing" title="Fuling jiabing">Fuling jiabing</a>, a traditional Beijing snack food, is a pancake (<i>bing</i>) resembling a flat disk with a filling made from <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fu_Ling" title="Fu Ling">fu ling</a></i>, a fungus used in traditional <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_medicine" title="Chinese medicine">Chinese medicine</a>. <a href="/wiki/Teahouse" title="Teahouse">Teahouses</a> are also common in Beijing.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Cloisonn%C3%A9" title="Cloisonné">cloisonné</a> (or <i>Jingtailan</i>, literally "Blue of <a href="/wiki/Jingtai_Emperor" title="Jingtai Emperor">Jingtai</a>") metalworking technique and tradition is a Beijing art speciality, and is one of the most revered traditional crafts in China. Cloisonné making requires elaborate and complicated processes which include base-hammering, copper-strip inlay, soldering, enamel-filling, enamel-firing, surface polishing and gilding.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup> Beijing's <a href="/wiki/Lacquerware" title="Lacquerware">lacquerware</a> is also well known for its sophisticated and intricate patterns and images carved into its surface, and the various decoration techniques of lacquer include "carved lacquer" and "engraved gold".
</p><p>Younger residents of Beijing have become more attracted to the nightlife, which has flourished in recent decades, breaking prior cultural traditions that had practically restricted it to the upper class.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[179]</a></sup> Today, <a href="/wiki/Houhai" title="Houhai">Houhai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sanlitun" title="Sanlitun">Sanlitun</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wudaokou" title="Wudaokou">Wudaokou</a> are Beijing's nightlife hotspots.
</p><p>In 2012 Beijing was named as City of Design and became part of the <a href="/wiki/Creative_Cities_Network" title="Creative Cities Network">UNESCO Creative Cities Network</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[180]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Places_of_interest">Places of interest</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Places of interest">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Major_National_Historical_and_Cultural_Sites_(Beijing)" title="Major National Historical and Cultural Sites (Beijing)">Major National Historical and Cultural Sites (Beijing)</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Beijing_landmarks" title="List of Beijing landmarks">List of Beijing landmarks</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>...the city remains an epicenter of tradition with the treasures of nearly 2,000 years as the imperial capital still on view—in the famed Forbidden City and in the city's lush pavilions and gardens...</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite><a href="/wiki/National_Geographic_Society" title="National Geographic Society">National Geographic</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-national_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-national-183">[181]</a></sup></cite></div></blockquote>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Qianmen_Street_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Qianmen_Street_1.jpg/220px-Qianmen_Street_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Qianmen_Street_1.jpg/330px-Qianmen_Street_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Qianmen_Street_1.jpg/440px-Qianmen_Street_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Qianmen_Street_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qianmen_Avenue" title="Qianmen Avenue">Qianmen Avenue</a>, a traditional commercial street outside Qianmen Gate along the southern Central Axis</div></div></div>
<p>At the historical heart of Beijing lies the <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_City" title="Forbidden City">Forbidden City</a>, the enormous palace compound that was the home of the emperors of the Ming and Qing dynasties;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[182]</a></sup> the Forbidden City hosts the Palace Museum, which contains imperial collections of Chinese art. Surrounding the Forbidden City are several former imperial gardens, parks and scenic areas, notably <a href="/wiki/Beihai_Park" title="Beihai Park">Beihai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shichahai" title="Shichahai">Shichahai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zhongnanhai" title="Zhongnanhai">Zhongnanhai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jingshan_Park" title="Jingshan Park">Jingshan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zhongshan_Park_(Beijing)" title="Zhongshan Park (Beijing)">Zhongshan</a>. These places, particularly Beihai Park, are described as masterpieces of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_garden" title="Chinese garden">Chinese gardening</a> art,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[183]</a></sup> and are tourist destinations of historical importance;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[184]</a></sup> in the modern era, Zhongnanhai has also been the political heart of various Chinese governments and regimes and is now the headquarters of the Chinese Communist Party and the State Council. From Tiananmen Square, right across from the Forbidden City, there are several notable sites, such as the Tiananmen, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qianmen" title="Qianmen">Qianmen</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Hall_of_the_People" title="Great Hall of the People">Great Hall of the People</a>, the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_China" title="National Museum of China">National Museum of China</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Monument_to_the_People%27s_Heroes" title="Monument to the People's Heroes">Monument to the People's Heroes</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mausoleum_of_Mao_Zedong" title="Mausoleum of Mao Zedong">Mausoleum of Mao Zedong</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Summer_Palace" title="Summer Palace">Summer Palace</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Old_Summer_Palace" title="Old Summer Palace">Old Summer Palace</a> both lie at the western part of the city; the former, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[185]</a></sup> contains a comprehensive collection of imperial gardens and palaces that served as the summer retreats for the Qing imperial family.
</p><p>Among the best known religious sites in the city is the <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Heaven" title="Temple of Heaven">Temple of Heaven</a> (<i>Tiantan</i>), located in southeastern Beijing, also a UNESCO World Heritage Site,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[186]</a></sup> where emperors of the Ming and Qing dynasties made visits for annual ceremonies of prayers to Heaven for good harvest. In the north of the city is the <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Earth" title="Temple of Earth">Temple of Earth</a> (<i>Ditan</i>), while the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temple_of_the_Sun" title="Temple of the Sun">Temple of the Sun</a> (<i>Ritan</i>) and the <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_the_Moon_(China)" title="Temple of the Moon (China)">Temple of the Moon</a> (<i>Yuetan</i>) lie in the eastern and western urban areas respectively. Other well-known temple sites include the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Dongyue_Temple" title="Beijing Dongyue Temple">Dongyue Temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tanzhe_Temple" title="Tanzhe Temple">Tanzhe Temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miaoying_Temple" title="Miaoying Temple">Miaoying Temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/White_Cloud_Temple" title="White Cloud Temple">White Cloud Temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yonghe_Temple" title="Yonghe Temple">Yonghe Temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fayuan_Temple" title="Fayuan Temple">Fayuan Temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wanshou_Temple" title="Wanshou Temple">Wanshou Temple</a> and <a href="/wiki/Big_Bell_Temple" title="Big Bell Temple">Big Bell Temple</a>. The city also has its own <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Temple_of_Confucius" title="Beijing Temple of Confucius">Confucius Temple</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/Guozijian_(Beijing)" title="Guozijian (Beijing)">Guozijian</a> or Imperial Academy. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Immaculate_Conception_in_Beijing" title="Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Beijing">Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception</a>, built in 1605, is the oldest Catholic church in Beijing. The <a href="/wiki/Niujie_Mosque" title="Niujie Mosque">Niujie Mosque</a> is the oldest mosque in Beijing, with a history stretching back over a thousand years.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C2%B7%CB%99%C2%B7ChinaUli2010%C2%B7.%C2%B7_Beijing_-_Forbidden_Town_-_panoramio_(81).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/%C2%B7%CB%99%C2%B7ChinaUli2010%C2%B7.%C2%B7_Beijing_-_Forbidden_Town_-_panoramio_%2881%29.jpg/220px-%C2%B7%CB%99%C2%B7ChinaUli2010%C2%B7.%C2%B7_Beijing_-_Forbidden_Town_-_panoramio_%2881%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/%C2%B7%CB%99%C2%B7ChinaUli2010%C2%B7.%C2%B7_Beijing_-_Forbidden_Town_-_panoramio_%2881%29.jpg/330px-%C2%B7%CB%99%C2%B7ChinaUli2010%C2%B7.%C2%B7_Beijing_-_Forbidden_Town_-_panoramio_%2881%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/%C2%B7%CB%99%C2%B7ChinaUli2010%C2%B7.%C2%B7_Beijing_-_Forbidden_Town_-_panoramio_%2881%29.jpg/440px-%C2%B7%CB%99%C2%B7ChinaUli2010%C2%B7.%C2%B7_Beijing_-_Forbidden_Town_-_panoramio_%2881%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C2%B7%CB%99%C2%B7ChinaUli2010%C2%B7.%C2%B7_Beijing_-_Forbidden_Town_-_panoramio_(81).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Inside the Forbidden City</div></div></div>
<p>Beijing contains several well-preserved pagodas and stone pagodas, such as the towering <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pagoda_of_Tianning_Temple_(Beijing)" title="Pagoda of Tianning Temple (Beijing)">Pagoda of Tianning Temple</a>, which was built during the Liao dynasty from 1100 to 1120, and the <a href="/wiki/Pagoda_of_Cishou_Temple" title="Pagoda of Cishou Temple">Pagoda of Cishou Temple</a>, which was built in 1576 during the Ming dynasty. Historically noteworthy stone bridges include the 12th-century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lugou_Bridge" title="Lugou Bridge">Lugou Bridge</a>, the 17th-century <a href="/wiki/Baliqiao" title="Baliqiao">Baliqiao</a> bridge, and the 18th-century <a href="/wiki/Jade_Belt_Bridge" title="Jade Belt Bridge">Jade Belt Bridge</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Ancient_Observatory" title="Beijing Ancient Observatory">Beijing Ancient Observatory</a> displays pre-telescopic spheres dating back to the Ming and Qing dynasties. The <a href="/wiki/Fragrant_Hills" title="Fragrant Hills">Fragrant Hills</a> (<i>Xiangshan</i>) is a public park that consists of natural landscaped areas as well as traditional and cultural relics. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_Botanical_Garden" title="Beijing Botanical Garden">Beijing Botanical Garden</a> exhibits over 6,000 species of plants, including a variety of trees, bushes and flowers, and an extensive <a href="/wiki/Peony" title="Peony">peony</a> garden. The <a href="/wiki/Taoranting_Park" title="Taoranting Park">Taoranting</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Longtan_Park" title="Longtan Park">Longtan</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_Chaoyang_Park" title="Beijing Chaoyang Park">Chaoyang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haidian_Park" title="Haidian Park">Haidian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Milu_Yuan" title="Milu Yuan">Milu Yuan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Purple_Bamboo_Park" title="Purple Bamboo Park">Zizhu Yuan</a> parks are some of the notable recreational parks in the city. The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Zoo" title="Beijing Zoo">Beijing Zoo</a> is a center of zoological research that also contains rare animals from various continents, including the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Giant_panda" title="Giant panda">giant panda</a>.
</p><p>There are 144 museums and galleries (as of June 2008<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>) in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-museum_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-museum-191">[189]</a></sup> In addition to the Palace Museum in the Forbidden City and the National Museum of China, other major museums include the <a href="/wiki/National_Art_Museum_of_China" title="National Art Museum of China">National Art Museum of China</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Capital_Museum" title="Capital Museum">Capital Museum</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Wanshou_Temple" title="Wanshou Temple">Beijing Art Museum</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Military_Museum_of_the_Chinese_People%27s_Revolution" title="Military Museum of the Chinese People's Revolution">Military Museum of the Chinese People's Revolution</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Geological_Museum_of_China" title="Geological Museum of China">Geological Museum of China</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="Beijing Museum of Natural History">Beijing Museum of Natural History</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Paleozoological_Museum_of_China" title="Paleozoological Museum of China">Paleozoological Museum of China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-museum_191-1"><a href="#cite_note-museum-191">[189]</a></sup>
</p><p>Located at the outskirts of urban Beijing, but within its municipality are the <a href="/wiki/Ming_tombs" title="Ming tombs">Thirteen Tombs of the Ming dynasty</a>, the lavish and elaborate burial sites of thirteen Ming emperors, which have been designated as part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Tombs_of_the_Ming_and_Qing_Dynasties" title="Imperial Tombs of the Ming and Qing Dynasties">Imperial Tombs of the Ming and Qing Dynasties</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[190]</a></sup> The archaeological <a href="/wiki/Peking_Man" title="Peking Man">Peking Man</a> site at <a href="/wiki/Zhoukoudian" title="Zhoukoudian">Zhoukoudian</a> is another World Heritage Site within the municipality,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[191]</a></sup> containing a wealth of discoveries, among them one of the first specimens of <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_erectus" title="Homo erectus">Homo erectus</a></i> and an assemblage of bones of the gigantic <a href="/wiki/Hyena" title="Hyena">hyena</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Pachycrocuta" title="Pachycrocuta">Pachycrocuta</a> brevirostris</i>. There are several sections of the UNESCO World Heritage Site <a href="/wiki/Great_Wall_of_China" title="Great Wall of China">Great Wall of China</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[192]</a></sup> most notably <a href="/wiki/Badaling" title="Badaling">Badaling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jinshanling" title="Jinshanling">Jinshanling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Simatai" title="Simatai">Simatai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mutianyu" title="Mutianyu">Mutianyu</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Travel_and_Tourism_Council" title="World Travel and Tourism Council">World Travel &amp; Tourism Council</a> (WTTC), Beijing is the second highest earning tourist city in the world after <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[193]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Intangible_Cultural_Heritage">Intangible Cultural Heritage</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Intangible Cultural Heritage">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Acrobatic_Performance_(10553642935).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2829" data-file-width="4453" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Beijing_Acrobatic_Performance_%2810553642935%29.jpg/220px-Beijing_Acrobatic_Performance_%2810553642935%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Beijing_Acrobatic_Performance_%2810553642935%29.jpg/330px-Beijing_Acrobatic_Performance_%2810553642935%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Beijing_Acrobatic_Performance_%2810553642935%29.jpg/440px-Beijing_Acrobatic_Performance_%2810553642935%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Acrobatic_Performance_(10553642935).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Beijing Acrobatic Performance (10553642935)</div></div></div>
<p>The cultural heritage of Beijing is rich and diverse. Starting 2006, the Beijing government started the process of selecting and preserving cultural heritages. Five cultural heritage lists have been published over the years. 288 distinct practices are categorized as cultural heritage. These 288 cultural heritages are further divided into ten categories, namely folk music, folk dance, traditional opera, melodious art, juggling and game, folk art, traditional handicraft, traditional medicine, folk literature and folklore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-第一批市级非物质文化遗产名录_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-第一批市级非物质文化遗产名录-196">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-第二批市级非物质文化遗产名录_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-第二批市级非物质文化遗产名录-197">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-第三批市级非物质文化遗产名录_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-第三批市级非物质文化遗产名录-198">[196]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-第四批市级非物质文化遗产名录_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-第四批市级非物质文化遗产名录-199">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-第五批市级非物质文化遗产名录_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-第五批市级非物质文化遗产名录-200">[198]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-list_of_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_and_the_Register_of_good_safeguarding_practices_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-list_of_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_and_the_Register_of_good_safeguarding_practices-201">[199]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="div-col">
<ul><li>Folk music
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Zhihua_Temple" title="Zhihua Temple">Zhihua Temple</a> music</li>
<li>Tongzhou <a href="/wiki/Sea_shanty" title="Sea shanty">shanty</a></li></ul></li>
<li>Folk dance
<ul><li>Tongzhou <a href="/wiki/Dragon_dance" title="Dragon dance">Dragon dance</a></li>
<li>Miliangtun <a href="/wiki/Stilts" title="Stilts">Stilts</a></li></ul></li>
<li>Traditional opera
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Kunqu" title="Kunqu">Kunqu</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peking_opera" title="Peking opera">Peking opera</a></li></ul></li>
<li>Melodious art
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Xiangsheng" title="Xiangsheng">Xiangsheng</a></li></ul></li>
<li>Acrobatic Performance and game
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Go_(game)" title="Go (game)">Weiqi(Go)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Xiangqi" title="Xiangqi">Xiangqi</a></li></ul></li>
<li>Folk art
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Ivory_carving" title="Ivory carving">Ivory carving</a></li></ul></li>
<li>Traditional handicraft
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Peking_duck" title="Peking duck">Peking duck</a> manufacturing techniques</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Cloisonn%C3%A9" title="Cloisonné">Cloisonné</a> manufacturing techniques</li></ul></li>
<li>Traditional medicine
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Tong_Ren_Tang" title="Tong Ren Tang">Tong Ren Tang</a> culture</li></ul></li>
<li>Folk literature
<ul><li><a class="external text" href="http://english.bjsjs.gov.cn/exploringshijingshan/historyculture/202012/t20201221_35552.html" rel="nofollow">Yongding River legend</a></li></ul></li>
<li>Folklore
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Miaohui" title="Miaohui">Miaohui</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Lantern_Festival" title="Lantern Festival">Lantern Festival</a></li></ul></li></ul>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Religion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gubeikou_Taoist_Temple_(20150215103242).JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Gubeikou_Taoist_Temple_%2820150215103242%29.JPG/220px-Gubeikou_Taoist_Temple_%2820150215103242%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Gubeikou_Taoist_Temple_%2820150215103242%29.JPG/330px-Gubeikou_Taoist_Temple_%2820150215103242%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Gubeikou_Taoist_Temple_%2820150215103242%29.JPG/440px-Gubeikou_Taoist_Temple_%2820150215103242%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gubeikou_Taoist_Temple_(20150215103242).JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Temple of the Goddess in <a href="/wiki/Gubeikou" title="Gubeikou">Gubeikou</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wanshoujingming-Baoge_Hall_of_Huode-Zhenjunmiao_Temple.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Wanshoujingming-Baoge_Hall_of_Huode-Zhenjunmiao_Temple.jpg/220px-Wanshoujingming-Baoge_Hall_of_Huode-Zhenjunmiao_Temple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Wanshoujingming-Baoge_Hall_of_Huode-Zhenjunmiao_Temple.jpg/330px-Wanshoujingming-Baoge_Hall_of_Huode-Zhenjunmiao_Temple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Wanshoujingming-Baoge_Hall_of_Huode-Zhenjunmiao_Temple.jpg/440px-Wanshoujingming-Baoge_Hall_of_Huode-Zhenjunmiao_Temple.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wanshoujingming-Baoge_Hall_of_Huode-Zhenjunmiao_Temple.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Fire God Temple in Di'anmen</div></div></div>
<p>The religious heritage of Beijing is rich and diverse as <a href="/wiki/Chinese_folk_religion" title="Chinese folk religion">Chinese folk religion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> all have significant historical presence in the city. As the national capital, the city also hosts the <a href="/wiki/State_Administration_for_Religious_Affairs" title="State Administration for Religious Affairs">State Administration for Religious Affairs</a> and various state-sponsored institutions of the leading religions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-religion1_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-religion1-202">[200]</a></sup> In recent decades, foreign residents have brought other religions to the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-religion1_202-1"><a href="#cite_note-religion1-202">[200]</a></sup> According to Wang Zhiyun of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences in 2010 there were 2.2 million Buddhists in the city, equal to 11.2% of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup> According to the Chinese General Social Survey of 2009, Christians constitute 0.78% of the city's population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wang2015_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wang2015-204">[202]</a></sup> According to a 2010 survey, Muslims constitute 1.76% of the population of Beijing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010-Islam_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-2010-Islam-205">[203]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Chinese_folk_religion_and_Taoism">Chinese folk religion and Taoism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Chinese folk religion and Taoism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Beijing has many temples dedicated to <a href="/wiki/Chinese_gods_and_immortals" title="Chinese gods and immortals">folk religious and communal deities</a>, many of which are being reconstructed or refurbished in the 2000s and 2010s. Yearly sacrifices to the <a href="/wiki/Tian" title="Tian">God of Heaven</a> (<span lang="zh"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%A5%AD%E5%A4%A9" title="wikt:祭天">祭天</a></span>; <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">jìtiān</span></i>) at the <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Heaven" title="Temple of Heaven">Temple of Heaven</a> have been resumed by <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucian</a> groups in the 2010s.
</p><p>There are temples dedicated to the worship of the Goddess (<span lang="zh"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%A8%98%E5%A8%98" title="wikt:娘娘">娘娘</a></span>; <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">Niángniáng</span></i>) in the city, one of them near the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Olympic_Village" title="Beijing Olympic Village">Olympic Village</a>, and they revolve around a major cult center at <a href="/wiki/Mount_Miaofeng" title="Mount Miaofeng">Mount Miaofeng</a>. There are also many temples consecrated to the <a href="/wiki/Dragon_King" title="Dragon King">Dragon God</a>, to the Medicine Master (<span lang="zh-Hans"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%8D%AF" title="wikt:药">药</a><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%8E%8B" title="wikt:王">王</a></span>; <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">Yàowáng</span></i>), to <a href="/wiki/Guan_Yu" title="Guan Yu">Divus Guan (Guan Yu)</a>, to the Fire God (<span lang="zh"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%81%AB%E7%A5%9E" title="wikt:火神">火神</a></span>; <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">Huǒshén</span></i>), to the <a href="/wiki/Caishen" title="Caishen">Wealth God</a>, temples of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chenghuangshen" title="Chenghuangshen">City God</a>, and at least one temple consecrated to the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Emperor" title="Yellow Emperor">Yellow Deity</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Big_Dipper" title="Big Dipper">Chariot</a> <a href="/wiki/Axis_mundi" title="Axis mundi">Shaft</a> (<span lang="zh-Hans"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%BD%A9%E8%BE%95" title="wikt:轩辕">轩辕</a><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E9%BB%84%E5%B8%9D" title="wikt:黄帝">黄帝</a></span>; <i><span lang="zh-Latn-pinyin">Xuānyuán Huángdì</span></i>) in <a href="/wiki/Pinggu_District" title="Pinggu District">Pinggu District</a>. Many of these temples are governed by the Beijing Taoist Association, such as the <a href="/wiki/Huode_Zhenjun_Temple" title="Huode Zhenjun Temple">Fire God Temple of the Shicha Lake</a>, while many others are not and are governed by popular committees and locals. A great Temple of Xuanyuan Huangdi will be built in Pinggu (possibly as an expansion of the already existing shrine) within 2020, and the temple will feature a statue of the deity which will be amongst the <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_statues" title="List of tallest statues">tallest in the world</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>The national <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Taoist_Association" title="Chinese Taoist Association">Chinese Taoist Association</a> and Chinese Taoist College have their headquarters at the <a href="/wiki/White_Cloud_Temple" title="White Cloud Temple">White Cloud Temple</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quanzhen_Taoism" title="Quanzhen Taoism">Quanzhen Taoism</a>, which was founded in 741 and rebuilt numerous times. The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Dongyue_Temple" title="Beijing Dongyue Temple">Beijing Dongyue Temple</a> outside Chaoyangmen is the largest temple of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zhengyi_Taoism" title="Zhengyi Taoism">Zhengyi Taoism</a> in the city. The local Beijing Taoist Association has its headquarters at the <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BCzu_Temple" title="Lüzu Temple">Lüzu Temple</a> near Fuxingmen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[206]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddhism">Buddhism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Buddhism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output <b>does not <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">cite</a> any <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">sources</a></b>.<span <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%E5%8D%81%E6%96%B9%E6%99%AE%E5%90%8C%E5%A1%94(%E5%83%A7%E4%BA%BA%E5%90%88%E8%91%AC%E5%A1%94)_-_Pagoda_for_Ordinary_Monks_-_2012.04_-_panoramio.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2400" data-file-width="3200" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/%E5%8D%81%E6%96%B9%E6%99%AE%E5%90%8C%E5%A1%94%28%E5%83%A7%E4%BA%BA%E5%90%88%E8%91%AC%E5%A1%94%29_-_Pagoda_for_Ordinary_Monks_-_2012.04_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-%E5%8D%81%E6%96%B9%E6%99%AE%E5%90%8C%E5%A1%94%28%E5%83%A7%E4%BA%BA%E5%90%88%E8%91%AC%E5%A1%94%29_-_Pagoda_for_Ordinary_Monks_-_2012.04_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/%E5%8D%81%E6%96%B9%E6%99%AE%E5%90%8C%E5%A1%94%28%E5%83%A7%E4%BA%BA%E5%90%88%E8%91%AC%E5%A1%94%29_-_Pagoda_for_Ordinary_Monks_-_2012.04_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-%E5%8D%81%E6%96%B9%E6%99%AE%E5%90%8C%E5%A1%94%28%E5%83%A7%E4%BA%BA%E5%90%88%E8%91%AC%E5%A1%94%29_-_Pagoda_for_Ordinary_Monks_-_2012.04_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/%E5%8D%81%E6%96%B9%E6%99%AE%E5%90%8C%E5%A1%94%28%E5%83%A7%E4%BA%BA%E5%90%88%E8%91%AC%E5%A1%94%29_-_Pagoda_for_Ordinary_Monks_-_2012.04_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-%E5%8D%81%E6%96%B9%E6%99%AE%E5%90%8C%E5%A1%94%28%E5%83%A7%E4%BA%BA%E5%90%88%E8%91%AC%E5%A1%94%29_-_Pagoda_for_Ordinary_Monks_-_2012.04_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%E5%8D%81%E6%96%B9%E6%99%AE%E5%90%8C%E5%A1%94(%E5%83%A7%E4%BA%BA%E5%90%88%E8%91%AC%E5%A1%94)_-_Pagoda_for_Ordinary_Monks_-_2012.04_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The tomb pagodas at <a href="/wiki/Tanzhe_Temple" title="Tanzhe Temple">Tanzhe Temple</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dongcheng,_Beijing,_China_-_panoramio_(84).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Dongcheng%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_panoramio_%2884%29.jpg/220px-Dongcheng%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_panoramio_%2884%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Dongcheng%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_panoramio_%2884%29.jpg/330px-Dongcheng%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_panoramio_%2884%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Dongcheng%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_panoramio_%2884%29.jpg/440px-Dongcheng%2C_Beijing%2C_China_-_panoramio_%2884%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dongcheng,_Beijing,_China_-_panoramio_(84).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Yonghe_Temple" title="Yonghe Temple">Yonghe Temple</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a></div></div></div>
<p>11% of the population of Beijing practices <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_Buddhism" title="East Asian Buddhism">East Asian Buddhism</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_Association_of_China" title="Buddhist Association of China">Buddhist Association of China</a>, the state's supervisory organ overseeing all <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddhist" title="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> institutions in mainland China, is headquartered in the <a href="/wiki/Guangji_Temple_(Beijing)" title="Guangji Temple (Beijing)">Guangji Temple</a>, a temple founded over 800 years ago during the <a href="/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(1115%E2%80%931234)" title="Jin dynasty (1115–1234)">Jin dynasty (1115–1234)</a> in what is now <a href="/wiki/Fuchengmen" title="Fuchengmen">Fuchengmennei</a> (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">阜成门内</span></span>). The Beijing Buddhist Association along with the Buddhist Choir and Orchestra are based in the <a href="/wiki/Guanghua_Temple_(Beijing)" title="Guanghua Temple (Beijing)">Guanghua Temple</a>, which dates to the Yuan dynasty over 700 years ago. The Buddhist Academy of China and its library are housed in the <a href="/wiki/Fayuan_Temple" title="Fayuan Temple">Fayuan Temple</a> near <a href="/wiki/Caishikou" title="Caishikou">Caishikou</a>. The Fayuan Temple, which dates to the <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> 1300 years ago, is the oldest temple in urban Beijing. The <a href="/wiki/Tongjiao_Temple" title="Tongjiao Temple">Tongjiao Temple</a> inside <a href="/wiki/Dongzhimen" title="Dongzhimen">Dongzhimen</a> is the city's only Buddhist nunnery.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Xihuang_Temple" title="Xihuang Temple">Xihuang Temple</a> originally dates to the <a href="/wiki/Liao_dynasty" title="Liao dynasty">Liao dynasty</a>. In 1651, the temple was commissioned by the <a href="/wiki/Shunzhi_Emperor" title="Shunzhi Emperor">Qing Emperor Shunzhi</a> to host the visit of the <a href="/wiki/5th_Dalai_Lama" title="5th Dalai Lama">Fifth Dalai Lama</a> to Beijing. Since then, this temple has hosted the <a href="/wiki/13th_Dalai_Lama" title="13th Dalai Lama">13th Dalai Lama</a> as well as the <a href="/wiki/Lobsang_Palden_Yeshe,_6th_Panchen_Lama" title="Lobsang Palden Yeshe, 6th Panchen Lama">Sixth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thubten_Choekyi_Nyima,_9th_Panchen_Lama" title="Thubten Choekyi Nyima, 9th Panchen Lama">Ninth</a> and <a href="/wiki/Choekyi_Gyaltsen,_10th_Panchen_Lama" title="Choekyi Gyaltsen, 10th Panchen Lama">Tenth</a> <a href="/wiki/Panchen_Lama" title="Panchen Lama">Panchen Lamas</a>.
</p><p>The largest Tibetan Buddhist Temple in Beijing is the <a href="/wiki/Yonghe_Temple" title="Yonghe Temple">Yonghe Temple</a>, which was decreed by the <a href="/wiki/Qianlong_Emperor" title="Qianlong Emperor">Qing Emperor Qianlong</a> in 1744 to serve as the residence and research facility for his Buddhist preceptor of <a href="/wiki/Changkya_R%C3%B6lp%C3%A9_Dorj%C3%A9" title="Changkya Rölpé Dorjé">Rölpé Dorjé</a> the third <a href="/wiki/Changkya_Khutukhtu" title="Changkya Khutukhtu">Changkya</a> (or living Buddha of <a href="/wiki/Inner_Mongolia" title="Inner Mongolia">Inner Mongolia</a>). The Yonghe Temple is so-named because it was the childhood residence of the <a href="/wiki/Yongzheng_Emperor" title="Yongzheng Emperor">Yongzheng Emperor</a>, and retains the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_glazed_roof_tile" title="Chinese glazed roof tile">glazed tiles</a> reserved for imperial palaces. While the "High-level Tibetan Buddhism College of China", China's highest institution college of Tibetan Buddhism, situated near the Yonghe Temple. The <a href="/wiki/Lingguang_Temple_(Beijing)" title="Lingguang Temple (Beijing)">Lingguang Temple</a> of <a href="/wiki/Badachu" title="Badachu">Badachu</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Western_Hills" title="Western Hills">Western Hills</a> also dates to the Tang dynasty. The temple's Zhaoxian Pagoda (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh-Hans">招仙塔</span></span>) was first built in 1071 during the Liao dynasty to hold a tooth relic of the <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Buddha</a>. The pagoda was destroyed during the <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Rebellion" title="Boxer Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a> and the tooth was discovered from its foundation. A new pagoda was built in 1964. The six aforementioned temples: Guangji, Guanghua, Tongjiao, Xihuang, Yonghe and Lingguang have been designated <a href="/wiki/National_Key_Buddhist_Temples_in_Han_Chinese_Area" title="National Key Buddhist Temples in Han Chinese Area">National Key Buddhist Temples in Han Chinese Area</a>.
</p><p>In addition, other notable temples in Beijing include the <a href="/wiki/Tanzhe_Temple" title="Tanzhe Temple">Tanzhe Temple</a> (founded in the <a href="/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(266%E2%80%93420)" title="Jin dynasty (266–420)">Jin dynasty (266–420)</a> is the oldest in the municipality), the <a href="/wiki/Tianning_Temple_(Beijing)" title="Tianning Temple (Beijing)">Tianning Temple</a> (oldest pagoda in the city), the <a href="/wiki/Miaoying_Temple" title="Miaoying Temple">Miaoying Temple</a> (famed for <a href="/wiki/Yuan_dynasty" title="Yuan dynasty">Yuan</a>-era white pagoda), the <a href="/wiki/Wanshou_Temple" title="Wanshou Temple">Wanshou Temple</a> (home to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_Art_Museum" title="Beijing Art Museum">Beijing Art Museum</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/Big_Bell_Temple" title="Big Bell Temple">Big Bell Temple</a> (Dazhong Temple).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Islam">Islam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Islam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Niujie_Mosques02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Niujie_Mosques02.jpg/220px-Niujie_Mosques02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Niujie_Mosques02.jpg/330px-Niujie_Mosques02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Niujie_Mosques02.jpg/440px-Niujie_Mosques02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Niujie_Mosques02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Niujie_Mosque" title="Niujie Mosque">Niujie Mosque</a></div></div></div>
<p>Beijing has about 70 mosques recognized by the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Association_of_China" title="Islamic Association of China">Islamic Association of China</a>, whose headquarters are located next to the <a href="/wiki/Niujie_Mosque" title="Niujie Mosque">Niujie Mosque</a>, the oldest mosque in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[207]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[208]</a></sup> The Niujie Mosque was founded in 996 during the Liao dynasty and is frequently visited by Muslim dignitaries. The Chinese Muslim community reportedly celebrated <a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">Ramadan</a> and made <a href="/wiki/Eid_prayers" title="Eid prayers">Eid prayers</a> at the mosque on 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>The largest mosque<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[211]</a></sup> in Beijing is ChangYing mosque, located in ChaoYang district, with an area of 8,400 square meters.
