</p><p>Other notable mosques in the old city include the <a href="/wiki/Dongsi_Mosque" title="Dongsi Mosque">Dongsi Mosque</a>, founded in 1346; the Huashi Mosque, founded in 1415; Nan Douya Mosque, near Chaoyangmen; Jinshifang Street Mosque, in Xicheng District; and the Dongzhimen Mosque.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[212]</a></sup> There are large mosques in outlying Muslim communities in Haidian, <a href="/wiki/Madian,_Beijing" title="Madian, Beijing">Madian</a>, Tongzhou, Changping, Changying, Shijingshan and Miyun. The China Islamic Institute is located in the Niujie neighborhood in Xicheng District.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Christianity">Christianity</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Christianity">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Xishikupic1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Xishikupic1.jpg/170px-Xishikupic1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Xishikupic1.jpg/255px-Xishikupic1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Xishikupic1.jpg/340px-Xishikupic1.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Xishikupic1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Saviour,_Beijing" title="Church of the Saviour, Beijing">Church of the Saviour</a>, also known as the Xishiku Church, built in 1703</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Catholicism">Catholicism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Catholicism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>In 1289, <a href="/wiki/John_of_Montecorvino" title="John of Montecorvino">John of Montecorvino</a> came to Beijing as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Franciscan" title="Franciscan">Franciscan</a> missionary with the order from the Pope. After meeting and receiving the support of <a href="/wiki/Kublai_Khan" title="Kublai Khan">Kublai Khan</a> in 1293, he built the first Catholic church in Beijing in 1305. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Patriotic_Catholic_Association" title="Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association">Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association</a> (CPCA), based in <a href="/wiki/Houhai" title="Houhai">Houhai</a> is the government oversight body for Catholics in mainland China. Notable Catholic churches in Beijing include:
</p>
<ul><li>the Nantang or <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Immaculate_Conception,_Beijing" title="Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, Beijing">Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception</a> also known as the Xuanwumen Church, which was founded in 1605 and whose current archbishop, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Li_Shan" title="Joseph Li Shan">Joseph Li Shan</a>, is one of the few bishops in China to have the support of both the Vatican and the CPCA.</li>
<li>the Dongtang or <a href="/wiki/St._Joseph%27s_Church,_Beijing" title="St. Joseph's Church, Beijing">St. Joseph's Church</a>, better known as the Wangfujing Church, founded in 1653.</li>
<li>the Beitang or <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Saviour,_Beijing" title="Church of the Saviour, Beijing">Church of the Saviour</a>, also known as the Xishiku Church, founded in 1703.</li>
<li>the Xitang or <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Our_Lady_of_Mount_Carmel,_Beijing" title="Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, Beijing">Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel</a> also known as the Xizhimen Church, founded in 1723.</li></ul>
<p>The National Seminary of Catholic Church in China is located in Daxing District.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Protestantism">Protestantism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Protestantism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>The earliest Protestant churches in Beijing were founded by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant_missions_in_China_1807%E2%80%931953" title="Protestant missions in China 1807–1953">British and American missionaries</a> in the second half of the 19th century. Protestant missionaries also opened schools, universities and hospitals which have become important civic institutions. Most of Beijing's Protestant churches were destroyed during the <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Rebellion" title="Boxer Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a> and afterwards rebuilt. In 1958, the 64 Protestant churches in the city are reorganized into four and overseen by the state through the <a href="/wiki/Three-Self_Patriotic_Movement" title="Three-Self Patriotic Movement">Three-Self Patriotic Movement</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Eastern_Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Eastern Orthodox">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>There was a significant amount of Orthodox Christians in Beijing. Orthodoxy came to Beijing with <a href="/wiki/Albazinians" title="Albazinians">Russian prisoners</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Sino-Russian_border_conflicts" title="Sino-Russian border conflicts">Sino-Russian border conflicts</a> of the 17th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[213]</a></sup> In 1956, Viktor, the bishop of Beijing returned to the Soviet Union, and the Soviet embassy took over the old cathedral and demolished it. In 2007, the Russian embassy built a new church in its garden to serve the Russian Orthodox Christians in Beijing.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Media">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Television_and_radio">Television and radio</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Television and radio">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CCTV-new-building.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2445" data-file-width="2370" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/CCTV-new-building.jpg/220px-CCTV-new-building.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/CCTV-new-building.jpg/330px-CCTV-new-building.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/CCTV-new-building.jpg/440px-CCTV-new-building.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CCTV-new-building.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/China_Central_Television_Headquarters_building" title="China Central Television Headquarters building">China Central Television Headquarters building</a> in CBD</div></div></div>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_Television" title="Beijing Television">Beijing Television</a> broadcasts on channels 1 through 10, and <a href="/wiki/China_Central_Television" title="China Central Television">China Central Television</a>, China's largest television network, maintains its headquarters in Beijing. Three radio stations feature programmes in English: <i>Hit FM</i> on FM 88.7, <i>Easy FM</i> by <a href="/wiki/China_Radio_International" title="China Radio International">China Radio International</a> on FM 91.5, and the newly launched <i>Radio 774</i> on AM 774. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_Radio_Stations" title="Beijing Radio Stations">Beijing Radio Stations</a> is the family of radio stations serving the city.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Press">Press</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Press">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The well-known <i><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Evening_News" title="Beijing Evening News">Beijing Evening News</a></i>, covering news about Beijing in Chinese, is distributed every afternoon. Other newspapers include <i><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Daily" title="Beijing Daily">Beijing Daily</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beijing_News" title="The Beijing News">The Beijing News</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Star_Daily" title="Beijing Star Daily">Beijing Star Daily</a></i>, the <i>Beijing Morning News</i>, and the <i><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Youth_Daily" title="Beijing Youth Daily">Beijing Youth Daily</a></i>, as well as English-language weeklies <i>Beijing Weekend</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Today" title="Beijing Today">Beijing Today</a></i>. The <i><a href="/wiki/People%27s_Daily" title="People's Daily">People's Daily</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Global_Times" title="Global Times">Global Times</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/China_Daily" title="China Daily">China Daily</a></i> (English) are published in Beijing as well.
</p><p>Publications primarily aimed at international visitors and the expatriate community include the English-language periodicals <i>Time Out Beijing</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/City_Weekend" title="City Weekend">City Weekend</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Beijing_This_Month" title="Beijing This Month">Beijing This Month</a></i>, <i>Beijing Talk</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/That%27s_Beijing" title="That's Beijing">That's Beijing</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beijinger" title="The Beijinger">The Beijinger</a></i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Beijing_Rock">Beijing Rock</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Beijing Rock">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Beijing rock (Chinese:  北京摇滚) is a wide variety of rock and roll music made by rock bands and solo artists from Beijing. The first rock band in Beijing is <a href="/wiki/Peking_All-Stars" title="Peking All-Stars">Peking All-Stars</a>, which was formed in 1979 by foreigners.
</p><p>Famous rock bands and solo artists from Beijing include <a href="/wiki/Cui_Jian" title="Cui Jian">Cui Jian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dou_Wei" title="Dou Wei">Dou Wei</a>, <a href="/wiki/He_Yong_(rock_musician)" title="He Yong (rock musician)">He Yong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pu_Shu" title="Pu Shu">Pu Shu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tang_Dynasty_(band)" title="Tang Dynasty (band)">Tang Dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Black_Panther_(band)" title="Black Panther (band)">Black Panther</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Flowers_(Chinese_band)" title="The Flowers (Chinese band)">The Flowers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wang_Feng_(singer)" title="Wang Feng (singer)">43 Baojia Street</a>, etc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[214]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Beijing_born_celebrities">Beijing born celebrities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Beijing born celebrities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p><b><a href="/wiki/Mei_Lanfang" title="Mei Lanfang">Mei Lanfang</a></b> (22 October 1894 – 8 August 1961) is a Beijing opera singer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[215]</a></sup> At age 15, he became an orphan and was adopted by his uncle's family. He started stage life in 1905 and became famous at 25 years old during performances in Japan. He was a pre-modern superstar, and famous for his portrayal of the Dan role, the elegant female archetype. After the Communist revolution, he served as an opera and performing art counselor in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[216]</a></sup> In November 2007, a theater namely Mei Lanfang Grand Theater opened in Xicheng District, Beijing to memorize him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p><b><a href="/wiki/Yuan_Longping" title="Yuan Longping">Yuan Longping</a></b> (7 September 1930- 22 May 2021) is a Chinese agronomist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup> He studied at Southwest Agricultural University. He encountered national famine at the beginning of his career. This made him determined to solve the food shortage in China. He worked as a pioneer on hybrid rice back in 1960. His research on cross breeding wild abortive rice with mutated male-sterile rice was later involve a lot of research around the globe. In 2004, Yuan Longping was awarded the World Food Prize because he conducted pioneer research that helped transform China from food deficiency to food security within three decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p><b><a href="/wiki/Cui_Jian" title="Cui Jian">Cui Jian</a></b> (August 1960 – present) is a Chinese rock singer. Various media praised him as the father of China's rock music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[220]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:23_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-:23-224">[222]</a></sup> He introduces western Rock to China in 1986 and mixed it with Chinese traditional music. Some of his songs are associated with movements in Chinese society such as "Nothing to My Name" and "Rock 'n' Roll on the New Long March". He also directed one movie called "Blue Sky Bones" at age 52.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:23_224-1"><a href="#cite_note-:23-224">[222]</a></sup>
</p><p><b><a href="/wiki/Yang_Jiang" title="Yang Jiang">Yang Jiang</a></b> (17 July 1911- 25 May 2016) is a Chinese writer and translator. She was educated at a Chinese university and Oxford University. Ms. Yang was known for her fiction, plays, essay, and nonfiction. She is the first person who translates "Don Quixote" into Chinese. Later, she taught at Tsinghua University for many years and retired in 1980. Some of her representative works are the essay collection "We three" and the novel "Baptism". She died on 25 May 2016, at a hospital in Beijing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p><b><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shu_Qingchun" title="Shu Qingchun">Shu Qingchun</a></b> (3 Feb 1899 – 24 August 1966), pen name Lao She, is a Chinese writer, linguist, and artist. He wrote eight million Chinese characters in entire life, is famous for long novels and scripts. In his iconic works, there are two long novels, two novellas, six short stories, and three scripts. Most of his works are depicting the poor life of Chinese citizens in the late Qing Dynasty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[224]</a></sup> He has been living in Britain, Singapore, and United States. During the Chinese Culture Revolution, he committed suicide by drowning in Taiping Lake.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Sports">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Events">Events</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Events">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2008_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony_-_Fireworks.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="696" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/2008_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony_-_Fireworks.jpg/220px-2008_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony_-_Fireworks.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/2008_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony_-_Fireworks.jpg/330px-2008_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony_-_Fireworks.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/2008_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony_-_Fireworks.jpg/440px-2008_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony_-_Fireworks.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2008_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony_-_Fireworks.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Fireworks above <a href="/wiki/Venues_of_the_2008_Summer_Olympics" title="Venues of the 2008 Summer Olympics">Olympic venues</a> during the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics_opening_ceremony" title="2008 Summer Olympics opening ceremony">opening ceremony</a> of the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Martial_arts_-_Fragrant_Hills.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1488" data-file-width="2240" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Martial_arts_-_Fragrant_Hills.JPG/220px-Martial_arts_-_Fragrant_Hills.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Martial_arts_-_Fragrant_Hills.JPG/330px-Martial_arts_-_Fragrant_Hills.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Martial_arts_-_Fragrant_Hills.JPG/440px-Martial_arts_-_Fragrant_Hills.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Martial_arts_-_Fragrant_Hills.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taijiquan" title="Taijiquan">Tai chi (Taijiquan)</a> practitioners at the <a href="/wiki/Fragrant_Hills" title="Fragrant Hills">Fragrant Hills</a> Park</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Workers%27_Stadium.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4912" data-file-width="7360" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Beijing_Workers%27_Stadium.jpg/220px-Beijing_Workers%27_Stadium.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Beijing_Workers%27_Stadium.jpg/330px-Beijing_Workers%27_Stadium.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Beijing_Workers%27_Stadium.jpg/440px-Beijing_Workers%27_Stadium.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Workers%27_Stadium.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_Workers%27_Stadium" title="Beijing Workers' Stadium">Beijing Workers' Stadium</a> at night as viewed from <a href="/wiki/Sanlitun" title="Sanlitun">Sanlitun</a></div></div></div>
<p>Beijing has hosted numerous international and national sporting events, the most notable was the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympic</a> and <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Paralympics" title="2008 Summer Paralympics">Paralympic</a> Games. Other <a href="/wiki/Multi-sport_event" title="Multi-sport event">multi-sport</a> international events held in Beijing include the 2001 <a href="/wiki/Universiade" title="Universiade">Universiade</a> and the 1990 <a href="/wiki/Asian_Games" title="Asian Games">Asian Games</a>. Single-sport international competitions include the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Marathon" title="Beijing Marathon">Beijing Marathon</a> (annually since 1981), <a href="/wiki/China_Open_(tennis)" title="China Open (tennis)">China Open of Tennis</a> (1993–97, annually since 2004), <a href="/wiki/ISU_Grand_Prix_of_Figure_Skating" title="ISU Grand Prix of Figure Skating">ISU Grand Prix of Figure Skating</a> <a href="/wiki/Cup_of_China" title="Cup of China">Cup of China</a> (2003, 2004, 2005, 2008, 2009 and 2010), <a href="/wiki/World_Professional_Billiards_and_Snooker_Association" title="World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association">WPBSA</a> <a href="/wiki/China_Open_(snooker)" title="China Open (snooker)">China Open for Snooker</a> (annually since 2005), <a href="/wiki/Union_Cycliste_Internationale" title="Union Cycliste Internationale">Union Cycliste Internationale</a> <a href="/wiki/Tour_of_Beijing" title="Tour of Beijing">Tour of Beijing</a> (since <a href="/wiki/2011_Tour_of_Beijing" title="2011 Tour of Beijing">2011</a>), 1961 <a href="/wiki/World_Table_Tennis_Championships" title="World Table Tennis Championships">World Table Tennis Championships</a>, <a href="/wiki/1987_IBF_World_Championships" title="1987 IBF World Championships">1987 IBF Badminton World Championships</a>, the <a href="/wiki/2004_AFC_Asian_Cup" title="2004 AFC Asian Cup">2004 AFC Asian Cup</a> (football), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2009_Barclays_Asia_Trophy" title="2009 Barclays Asia Trophy">2009 Barclays Asia Trophy</a> (football). Beijing hosted the <a href="/wiki/2015_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2015 World Championships in Athletics">2015 IAAF World Championships in Athletics</a>.
</p><p>Beijing's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LeSports_Center" title="LeSports Center">LeSports Center</a> is one of the main venues for the <a href="/wiki/2019_FIBA_Basketball_World_Cup" title="2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup">2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city hosted the second <a href="/wiki/National_Games_of_China" title="National Games of China">Chinese National Games</a> in 1914 and the first four <a href="/wiki/National_Games_of_China" title="National Games of China">National Games of China</a> in 1959, 1965, 1975, 1979, respectively, and co-hosted the 1993 National Games with <a href="/wiki/Sichuan" title="Sichuan">Sichuan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Qingdao" title="Qingdao">Qingdao</a>. Beijing also hosted the inaugural <a href="/wiki/National_Peasants%27_Games" title="National Peasants' Games">National Peasants' Games</a> in 1988 and the sixth National Minority Games in 1999.
</p><p>In November 2013, Beijing made a <a href="/wiki/Beijing_bid_for_the_2022_Winter_Olympics" title="Beijing bid for the 2022 Winter Olympics">bid</a> to host the <a href="/wiki/2022_Winter_Olympics" title="2022 Winter Olympics">2022 Winter Olympics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-:2-36">[35]</a></sup> On 31 July 2015, the International Olympic Committee awarded the 2022 Winter Olympics to the city becoming the first ever to host both Summer and Winter Olympics also for the <a href="/wiki/2022_Winter_Paralympics" title="2022 Winter Paralympics">2022 Winter Paralympics</a> becoming the first ever to host both Summer and Winter Paralympics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_37-1"><a href="#cite_note-:3-37">[36]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Venues">Venues</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Venues">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Major sporting venues in the city include the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_National_Stadium" title="Beijing National Stadium">National Stadium</a>, also known as the "Birds' Nest",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[228]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_National_Aquatics_Center" title="Beijing National Aquatics Center">National Aquatics Center</a>, also known as the "Water Cube", <a href="/wiki/Beijing_National_Indoor_Stadium" title="Beijing National Indoor Stadium">National Indoor Stadium</a>, all in the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Green" title="Olympic Green">Olympic Green</a> to the north of downtown; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MasterCard_Center" title="MasterCard Center">MasterCard Center</a> at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wukesong_Station" title="Wukesong Station">Wukesong</a> west of downtown; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Workers_Stadium" title="Workers Stadium">Workers' Stadium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Workers_Indoor_Arena" title="Workers Indoor Arena">Workers' Arena</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sanlitun" title="Sanlitun">Sanlitun</a> just east of downtown and the <a href="/wiki/Capital_Indoor_Stadium" title="Capital Indoor Stadium">Capital Arena</a> in Baishiqiao, northeast of downtown. In addition, many universities in the city have their own sport facilities.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Clubs">Clubs</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Clubs">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Professional sports teams based in Beijing include:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="div-col">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/China_Baseball_League" title="China Baseball League">China Baseball League</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Tigers" title="Beijing Tigers">Beijing Tigers</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chinese_Basketball_Association" title="Chinese Basketball Association">Chinese Basketball Association</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Ducks" title="Beijing Ducks">Beijing Ducks</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Royal_Fighters" title="Beijing Royal Fighters">Beijing Royal Fighters</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Chinese_Basketball_Association" title="Women's Chinese Basketball Association">Women's Chinese Basketball Association</a>
<ul><li>Beijing Shougang</li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kontinental_Hockey_League" title="Kontinental Hockey League">Kontinental Hockey League</a>
<ul><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/HC_Kunlun_Red_Star" title="HC Kunlun Red Star">HC Kunlun Red Star</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chinese_Super_League" title="Chinese Super League">Chinese Super League</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Guoan_F.C." title="Beijing Guoan F.C.">Beijing Guoan</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/China_League_One" title="China League One">China League One</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Sport_University_F.C." title="Beijing Sport University F.C.">Beijing BSU</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/China_League_Two" title="China League Two">China League Two</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Institute_of_Technology_F.C." title="Beijing Institute of Technology F.C.">Beijing BIT</a></li></ul></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Women%27s_National_League" title="Chinese Women's National League">Chinese Women's National League</a>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Beijing_BG_Phoenix_F.C." title="Beijing BG Phoenix F.C.">Beijing BG Phoenix</a></li></ul></li></ul>
</div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Olympians" title="Beijing Olympians">Beijing Olympians</a> of the <a href="/wiki/American_Basketball_Association_(2000%E2%80%93present)" title="American Basketball Association (2000–present)">American Basketball Association</a>, formerly a <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Basketball_Association" title="Chinese Basketball Association">Chinese Basketball Association</a> team, kept their name and maintained a roster of primarily Chinese players after moving to <a href="/wiki/Maywood,_California" title="Maywood, California">Maywood, California</a> in 2005.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/China_Bandy_Federation" title="China Bandy Federation">China Bandy Federation</a> is based in Beijing, one of several cities in which the potential for <a href="/wiki/Bandy" title="Bandy">bandy</a> development is explored.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[229]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Transportation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Beijing" title="Transport in Beijing">Transport in Beijing</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijingrailwaystation_night.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Beijingrailwaystation_night.jpg/220px-Beijingrailwaystation_night.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Beijingrailwaystation_night.jpg/330px-Beijingrailwaystation_night.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Beijingrailwaystation_night.jpg/440px-Beijingrailwaystation_night.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijingrailwaystation_night.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Beijing_railway_station" title="Beijing railway station">Beijing railway station</a>, one of several rail stations in the city</div></div></div>
<p>Beijing is an important <a href="/wiki/Transport_hub" title="Transport hub">transport hub</a> in <a href="/wiki/North_China" title="North China">North China</a> with six <a href="/wiki/Ring_roads_of_Beijing" title="Ring roads of Beijing">ring roads</a>, 1167 km (725 miles) of expressways,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19nj_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-19nj-232">[230]</a></sup> 15 National Highways, nine conventional railways, and six high-speed railways converging on the city.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rail_and_high-speed_rail">Rail and high-speed rail</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Rail and high-speed rail">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Beijing serves as a large rail hub in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Rail transport in the People's Republic of China">China's railway network</a>. Ten conventional rail lines radiate from the city to: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing-Shanghai_Railway" title="Beijing-Shanghai Railway">Shanghai (Jinghu Line)</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Guangzhou_Railway" title="Beijing–Guangzhou Railway">Guangzhou (Jingguang Line)</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Kowloon_Railway" title="Beijing–Kowloon Railway">Kowloon (Jingjiu Line)</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing-Harbin_Railway" title="Beijing-Harbin Railway">Harbin (Jingha Line)</a> (including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing-Qinhuangdao_Railway" title="Beijing-Qinhuangdao Railway">Qinhuangdao (Jingqin Line)</a>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing-Baotou_Railway" title="Beijing-Baotou Railway">Baotou (Jingbao Line)</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Chengde_Railway" title="Beijing–Chengde Railway">Chengde (Jingcheng Line)</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Tongliao_Railway" title="Beijing–Tongliao Railway">Tongliao, Inner Mongolia (Jingtong Line)</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Yuanping_Railway" title="Beijing–Yuanping Railway">Yuanping, Shanxi (Jingyuan Line)</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fengtai%E2%80%93Shacheng_Railway" title="Fengtai–Shacheng Railway">Shacheng, Hebei (Fengsha Line)</a>. In addition, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Datong%E2%80%93Qinhuangdao_Railway" title="Datong–Qinhuangdao Railway">Datong–Qinhuangdao Railway</a> passes through the municipality to the north of the city.
</p><p>Beijing also has six <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail" title="High-speed rail">high-speed rail</a> lines: the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing-Tianjin_Intercity_Railway" title="Beijing-Tianjin Intercity Railway">Beijing-Tianjin Intercity Railway</a>, which opened in 2008; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing-Shanghai_High-Speed_Railway" title="Beijing-Shanghai High-Speed Railway">Beijing-Shanghai High-Speed Railway</a>, which opened in 2011; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Guangzhou%E2%80%93Shenzhen%E2%80%93Hong_Kong_High-Speed_Railway" title="Beijing–Guangzhou–Shenzhen–Hong Kong High-Speed Railway">Beijing–Guangzhou High-Speed Railway</a>, which opened in 2012; and the <a href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Xiong%27an_intercity_railway" title="Beijing–Xiong'an intercity railway">Beijing–Xiong'an intercity railway</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Zhangjiakou_intercity_railway" title="Beijing–Zhangjiakou intercity railway">Beijing–Zhangjiakou intercity railway</a>, both of which opened in 2019. The <a href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Shenyang_high-speed_railway" title="Beijing–Shenyang high-speed railway">Beijing–Shenyang high-speed railway</a> was completed in 2021.
</p><p>The city's main railway stations are the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_railway_station" title="Beijing railway station">Beijing railway station</a>, which opened in 1959; the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_West_railway_station" title="Beijing West railway station">Beijing West railway station</a>, which opened in 1996; and the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_South_railway_station" title="Beijing South railway station">Beijing South railway station</a>, which was rebuilt into the city's high-speed railway station in 2008; The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_North_railway_station" title="Beijing North railway station">Beijing North railway station</a>, was first built in 1905 and expanded in 2009; The <a href="/wiki/Qinghe_railway_station" title="Qinghe railway station">Qinghe railway station</a>, was first built in 1905 and expanded in 2019; The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Chaoyang_railway_station" title="Beijing Chaoyang railway station">Beijing Chaoyang railway station</a> opened in 2021; The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Fengtai_railway_station" title="Beijing Fengtai railway station">Beijing Fengtai railway station</a> opened in 2022; and the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Sub-Center_railway_station" title="Beijing Sub-Center railway station">Beijing Sub-Center railway station</a> is under construction.
</p><p>Smaller stations in the city including <a href="/wiki/Beijing_East_railway_station" title="Beijing East railway station">Beijing East railway station</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Daxing_Airport_station" title="Daxing Airport station">Daxing Airport station</a> handle mainly commuter passenger traffic. In outlying suburbs and counties of Beijing, there are over 40 railway stations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[231]</a></sup>
</p><p>From Beijing, <a href="/wiki/Passenger_rail_transport_in_China" title="Passenger rail transport in China">direct passenger train service</a> is available to most large cities in China. International train service is available to <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>, Russia, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>. Passenger trains in China are numbered according to their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Railroad_direction" title="Railroad direction">direction</a> in relation to Beijing.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Roads_and_expressways">Roads and expressways</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Roads and expressways">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Expressways_of_Beijing" title="Expressways of Beijing">Expressways of Beijing</a> and <a href="/wiki/China_National_Highways_of_Beijing" title="China National Highways of Beijing">China National Highways of Beijing</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:G6_Badaling_Expressway_overpass_seen_from_Great_Wall.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2856" data-file-width="4788" decoding="async" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/G6_Badaling_Expressway_overpass_seen_from_Great_Wall.jpg/220px-G6_Badaling_Expressway_overpass_seen_from_Great_Wall.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/G6_Badaling_Expressway_overpass_seen_from_Great_Wall.jpg/330px-G6_Badaling_Expressway_overpass_seen_from_Great_Wall.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/G6_Badaling_Expressway_overpass_seen_from_Great_Wall.jpg/440px-G6_Badaling_Expressway_overpass_seen_from_Great_Wall.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:G6_Badaling_Expressway_overpass_seen_from_Great_Wall.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/G6_Beijing%E2%80%93Lhasa_Expressway" title="G6 Beijing–Lhasa Expressway">Badaling Expressway</a> overpass near the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Wall" title="Great Wall">Great Wall</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Road_sign_at_Yongfeng_Rd,_Houchangcun_Rd_(20200105224131).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2688" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Road_sign_at_Yongfeng_Rd%2C_Houchangcun_Rd_%2820200105224131%29.jpg/220px-Road_sign_at_Yongfeng_Rd%2C_Houchangcun_Rd_%2820200105224131%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Road_sign_at_Yongfeng_Rd%2C_Houchangcun_Rd_%2820200105224131%29.jpg/330px-Road_sign_at_Yongfeng_Rd%2C_Houchangcun_Rd_%2820200105224131%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Road_sign_at_Yongfeng_Rd%2C_Houchangcun_Rd_%2820200105224131%29.jpg/440px-Road_sign_at_Yongfeng_Rd%2C_Houchangcun_Rd_%2820200105224131%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Road_sign_at_Yongfeng_Rd,_Houchangcun_Rd_(20200105224131).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Typical Beijing traffic signage found at intersections</div></div></div>
<p>Beijing is connected by road links to all parts of China as part of the National Trunk Road Network. Many <a href="/wiki/Expressways_of_China" title="Expressways of China">expressways of China</a> serve Beijing, as do 15 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/China_National_Highway" title="China National Highway">China National Highways</a>. Beijing's urban transport is dependent upon the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ring_Roads_of_Beijing" title="Ring Roads of Beijing">ring roads</a>" that concentrically surround the city, with the <a href="/wiki/Forbidden_City" title="Forbidden City">Forbidden City</a> area marked as the geographical center for the ring roads. The ring roads appear more rectangular than ring-shaped. There is no official "1st Ring Road". The <a href="/wiki/2nd_Ring_Road" title="2nd Ring Road">2nd Ring Road</a> is located in the inner city. Ring roads tend to resemble <a href="/wiki/Controlled-access_highway" title="Controlled-access highway">expressways</a> progressively as they extend outwards, with the <a href="/wiki/5th_Ring_Road" title="5th Ring Road">5th</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/6th_Ring_Road" title="6th Ring Road">6th Ring Roads</a> being full-standard national expressways, linked to other roads only by interchanges. Expressways to other regions of China are generally accessible from the <a href="/wiki/3rd_Ring_Road_(Beijing)" title="3rd Ring Road (Beijing)">3rd Ring Road</a> outward. A final outer orbital, the <a href="/wiki/G95_Capital_Area_Loop_Expressway" title="G95 Capital Area Loop Expressway">Capital Area Loop Expressway (G95)</a>, was fully opened in 2018 and will extend into neighboring <a href="/wiki/Tianjin" title="Tianjin">Tianjin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hebei" title="Hebei">Hebei</a>.
</p><p>Within the urban core, city streets generally follow the checkerboard pattern of the ancient capital. Many of Beijing's boulevards and streets with "inner" and "outer" are still named in relation to gates in the city wall, though most gates no longer stand. Traffic jams are a major concern. Even outside of rush hour, several roads still remain clogged with traffic.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Modern_Beijing_Traffic.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2336" data-file-width="3504" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c6/Modern_Beijing_Traffic.jpg/220px-Modern_Beijing_Traffic.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c6/Modern_Beijing_Traffic.jpg/330px-Modern_Beijing_Traffic.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c6/Modern_Beijing_Traffic.jpg/440px-Modern_Beijing_Traffic.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Modern_Beijing_Traffic.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Traffic jam in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_CBD" title="Beijing CBD">Beijing CBD</a></div></div></div>
<p>Beijing's urban design layout further exacerbates transportation problems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[232]</a></sup> The authorities have introduced several bus lanes, which only public buses can use during rush hour. In the beginning of 2010, Beijing had 4 million registered automobiles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[233]</a></sup> By the end of 2010, the government forecast 5 million. In 2010, new car registrations in Beijing averaged 15,500 per week.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[234]</a></sup>
</p><p>Towards the end of 2010, the city government announced a series of drastic measures to tackle traffic jams, including limiting the number of new license plates issued to passenger cars to 20,000 a month and barring cars with non-Beijing plates from entering areas within the Fifth Ring Road during rush hour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[235]</a></sup> More restrictive measures are also reserved during major events or heavily polluted weather.
</p><p>Road signs began to be standardized with both Chinese and English names displayed, with location names using pinyin, in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[236]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Air">Air</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Air">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Beijing_Capital_International_Airport">Beijing Capital International Airport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: Beijing Capital International Airport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Capital_International_Airport_Terminal_3_Interior_20090818.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Beijing_Capital_International_Airport_Terminal_3_Interior_20090818.jpg/220px-Beijing_Capital_International_Airport_Terminal_3_Interior_20090818.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Beijing_Capital_International_Airport_Terminal_3_Interior_20090818.jpg/330px-Beijing_Capital_International_Airport_Terminal_3_Interior_20090818.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Beijing_Capital_International_Airport_Terminal_3_Interior_20090818.jpg/440px-Beijing_Capital_International_Airport_Terminal_3_Interior_20090818.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Capital_International_Airport_Terminal_3_Interior_20090818.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Terminal 3 of the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Capital_International_Airport" title="Beijing Capital International Airport">Beijing Capital International Airport</a></div></div></div>
<p>Beijing has two of the world's largest airports. The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Capital_International_Airport" title="Beijing Capital International Airport">Beijing Capital International Airport</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IATA" title="IATA">IATA</a>: PEK) located 32 kilometres (20 mi) northeast of the city center in <a href="/wiki/Chaoyang_District,_Beijing" title="Chaoyang District, Beijing">Chaoyang District</a> bordering <a href="/wiki/Shunyi_District" title="Shunyi District">Shunyi District</a>, is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by passenger traffic">second busiest airport in the world</a> after <a href="/wiki/Atlanta" title="Atlanta">Atlanta</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hartsfield-Jackson_Atlanta_International_Airport" title="Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport">Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ACI_aero_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-ACI_aero-22">[21]</a></sup> Capital Airport's Terminal 3, built during the expansion for the 2008 Olympics, is one of the largest in the world. Capital Airport is the main hub for <a href="/wiki/Air_China" title="Air China">Air China</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hainan_Airlines" title="Hainan Airlines">Hainan Airlines</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Airport_Expressway_(Beijing)" title="Airport Expressway (Beijing)">Airport Expressway</a> and <a href="/wiki/2nd_Airport_Expressway" title="2nd Airport Expressway">Second Airport Expressway</a>, connect to Capital Airport from the northeast and east of the city center, respectively. Driving time from city center is about 40 minutes under normal traffic conditions. The <a href="/wiki/Capital_Airport_Express" title="Capital Airport Express">Capital Airport Express</a> line of <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Subway" title="Beijing Subway">Beijing Subway</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_Airport_Bus" title="Beijing Airport Bus">Capital Airport Bus</a> serves the Capital Airport.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport">Beijing Daxing International Airport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Beijing Daxing International Airport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport_13.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4110" data-file-width="6165" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport_13.jpg/220px-Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport_13.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport_13.jpg/330px-Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport_13.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport_13.jpg/440px-Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport_13.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport_13.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport" title="Beijing Daxing International Airport">Beijing Daxing International Airport</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Daxing_International_Airport" title="Beijing Daxing International Airport">Beijing Daxing International Airport</a> (IATA: PKX) located 46 kilometres (29 mi) south of the city in <a href="/wiki/Daxing_District" title="Daxing District">Daxing District</a> bordering the city of <a href="/wiki/Langfang" title="Langfang">Langfang</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hebei_Province" title="Hebei Province">Hebei Province</a>, opened on 25 September 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-carnoc20160112_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-carnoc20160112-240">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[239]</a></sup> The Daxing Airport has one of the world's largest terminal buildings and is expected to be a major airport serving Beijing, Tianjin and northern Hebei Province. Daxing Airport is connected to the city via the <a href="/wiki/Beijing%E2%80%93Xiong%27an_intercity_railway" title="Beijing–Xiong'an intercity railway">Beijing–Xiong'an intercity railway</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Daxing_Airport_Express" title="Daxing Airport Express">Daxing Airport Express</a> line of the Beijing Subway and two expressways.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_airports">Other airports</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Other airports">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>With the opening of the Daxing Airport in September 2019, the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Nanyuan_Airport" title="Beijing Nanyuan Airport">Beijing Nanyuan Airport</a> (IATA:NAY), located 13 kilometres (8.1 mi) south of center in <a href="/wiki/Fengtai_District" title="Fengtai District">Fengtai District</a>, has been closed to civilian airline service. Other airports in the city at Liangxiang, Xijiao, Shahe and Badaling are primarily for military use.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Visa_requirements_for_air_passengers">Visa requirements for air passengers</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Visa requirements for air passengers">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>As of 1 January 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, tourists from 45 countries are permitted a 72-hour visa-free stay in Beijing. The 45 countries include Singapore, Japan, the United States, Canada, all EU and EEA countries (except Norway and Liechtenstein), Switzerland, Brazil, Argentina and Australia. The programme benefits transit and business travellers<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[240]</a></sup> with the 72 hours calculated starting from the moment visitors receive their transit stay permits rather than the time of their plane's arrival. Foreign visitors are not permitted to leave Beijing for other Chinese cities during the 72 hours.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beijing_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beijing-243">[241]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_transit">Public transit</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=54" title="Edit section: Public transit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:01_111_and_01_031_at_Yangzha_Middle_School_(20211027075355).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3962" data-file-width="5943" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/01_111_and_01_031_at_Yangzha_Middle_School_%2820211027075355%29.jpg/220px-01_111_and_01_031_at_Yangzha_Middle_School_%2820211027075355%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/01_111_and_01_031_at_Yangzha_Middle_School_%2820211027075355%29.jpg/330px-01_111_and_01_031_at_Yangzha_Middle_School_%2820211027075355%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/01_111_and_01_031_at_Yangzha_Middle_School_%2820211027075355%29.jpg/440px-01_111_and_01_031_at_Yangzha_Middle_School_%2820211027075355%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:01_111_and_01_031_at_Yangzha_Middle_School_(20211027075355).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Line_1,_Beijing_Subway" title="Line 1, Beijing Subway">Line 1</a> trains on the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Subway" title="Beijing Subway">Beijing Subway</a>, which is among the longest and busiest <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">rapid transit</a> systems in the world</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:4838397_at_Tian%27anmen_(20200825105132).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4061" data-file-width="6091" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/4838397_at_Tian%27anmen_%2820200825105132%29.jpg/220px-4838397_at_Tian%27anmen_%2820200825105132%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/4838397_at_Tian%27anmen_%2820200825105132%29.jpg/330px-4838397_at_Tian%27anmen_%2820200825105132%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/4838397_at_Tian%27anmen_%2820200825105132%29.jpg/440px-4838397_at_Tian%27anmen_%2820200825105132%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:4838397_at_Tian%27anmen_(20200825105132).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An articulated <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_bus" title="Beijing bus">Beijing bus</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Subway" title="Beijing Subway">Beijing Subway</a>, which began operating in 1969, now has 25 lines, 459 <a href="/wiki/List_of_Beijing_Subway_stations" title="List of Beijing Subway stations">stations</a>, and 783 km (487 mi) of <a href="/wiki/Line_length" title="Line length">lines</a>. It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metro_systems" title="List of metro systems">longest subway system in the world</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metro_systems_by_annual_passenger_rides" title="Metro systems by annual passenger rides">first in annual ridership</a> with 3.66 billion rides delivered in 2016. In 2013, with a flat fare of <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">¥</a>2.00 (US$0.31) per ride with unlimited transfers on all lines except the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Airport_Express,_Beijing_Subway" title="Airport Express, Beijing Subway">Airport Express</a>, the subway was also the most affordable <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rapid_transit_in_China" title="Rapid transit in China">rapid transit system in China</a>. The subway is undergoing rapid expansion and is expected to reach 30 lines, 450 stations, 1,050 kilometres (650 mi) in length by 2022. When fully implemented, 95% of residents inside the <a href="/wiki/4th_Ring_Road" title="4th Ring Road">Fourth Ring Road</a> will be able to walk to a station in 15 minutes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[242]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (October 2021)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Suburban_Railway" title="Beijing Suburban Railway">Beijing Suburban Railway</a> provides commuter rail service to outlying suburbs of the municipality.
</p><p>On 28 December 2014, the Beijing Subway switched to a distance-based fare system from a fixed fare for all lines except the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Airport_Express,_Beijing_Subway" title="Airport Express, Beijing Subway">Airport Express</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-english.cri.cn_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-english.cri.cn-245">[243]</a></sup> Under the new system a trip under <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style>6 km (<span class="frac" role="math">3<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>⁄<span class="den">2</span></span> mi) will cost <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">¥</a>3.00(US$0.49), an additional <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">¥</a>1.00 will be added for the next <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1020198016" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/>6 km (<span class="frac" role="math">3<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>⁄<span class="den">2</span></span> mi) and the next 10 km (6 mi) until the distance for the trip reaches 32 km (20 mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-english.cri.cn_245-1"><a href="#cite_note-english.cri.cn-245">[243]</a></sup> For every 20 kilometres (12 miles) after the original 32 kilometres (20 miles) an additional <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">¥</a>1.00 is added.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-english.cri.cn_245-2"><a href="#cite_note-english.cri.cn-245">[243]</a></sup> For example, a 50-kilometre (31-mile) trip would cost <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">¥</a> 8.00.
</p><p>There are nearly 1,000 <a href="/wiki/Beijing_Bus" title="Beijing Bus">public bus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Trolleybus" title="Trolleybus">trolleybus</a> lines in the city, including four <a href="/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit" title="Bus rapid transit">bus rapid transit</a> lines. Standard bus fares are as low as ¥1.00 when purchased with the <i><a href="/wiki/Yikatong" title="Yikatong">Yikatong</a></i> metrocard.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Taxi">Taxi</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=55" title="Edit section: Taxi">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Metered <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taxicab" title="Taxicab">taxi</a> in Beijing start at ¥13 for the first 3 kilometres (1.9 mi), ¥2.3 <a href="/wiki/Renminbi" title="Renminbi">Renminbi</a> per additional 1 kilometre (0.62 mi) and ¥1 per ride fuel surcharge, not counting idling fees which are ¥2.3 (¥4.6 during rush hours of 7–9 am and 5–7 pm) per 5 minutes of standing or running at speeds lower than 12 kilometres per hour (7.5 mph). Most taxis are <a href="/wiki/Hyundai_Elantra" title="Hyundai Elantra">Hyundai Elantras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hyundai_Sonata" title="Hyundai Sonata">Hyundai Sonatas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot" title="Peugeot">Peugeots</a>, <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn" title="Citroën">Citroëns</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Jetta" title="Volkswagen Jetta">Volkswagen Jettas</a>. After 15 kilometres (9.3 mi), the base fare increases by 50% (but is only applied to the portion <i>over</i> that distance). Different companies have special colours combinations painted on their vehicles. Usually registered taxis have yellowish brown as basic hue, with another color of Prussian blue, hunter green, white, umber, tyrian purple, rufous, or sea green. Between 11 pm and 5 am, there is also a 20% fee increase. Rides over 15 km (9 mi) and between 23:00 and 06:00 incur both charges, for a total increase of 80%. Tolls during trip should be covered by customers and the costs of trips beyond Beijing city limits should be negotiated with the driver. The cost of unregistered taxis is also subject to negotiation with the driver.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bicycles">Bicycles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=56" title="Edit section: Bicycles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Changan_Avenue_(4011960012).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Changan_Avenue_%284011960012%29.jpg/220px-Changan_Avenue_%284011960012%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Changan_Avenue_%284011960012%29.jpg/330px-Changan_Avenue_%284011960012%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Changan_Avenue_%284011960012%29.jpg/440px-Changan_Avenue_%284011960012%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Changan_Avenue_(4011960012).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Bicyclists during rush hour at the Chang'an Avenue, 2009</div></div></div>
<p>Beijing has long been well known for the number of bicycles on its streets. Although the rise of motor traffic has created a great deal of congestion and bicycle use has declined, bicycles are still an important form of local transportation. Many cyclists can be seen on most roads in the city, and most of the main roads have dedicated <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bicycle_lanes" title="Bicycle lanes">bicycle lanes</a>. Beijing is relatively flat, which makes cycling convenient. The rise of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electric_bicycles" title="Electric bicycles">electric bicycles</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electric_scooters" title="Electric scooters">electric scooters</a>, which have similar speeds and use the same cycle lanes, may have brought about a revival in bicycle-speed two-wheeled transport. It is possible to cycle to most parts of the city. Because of the growing traffic congestion, the authorities have indicated more than once that they wish to encourage cycling, but it is not clear whether there is sufficient will to translate that into action on a significant scale.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[244]</a></sup> On 30 March 2019, a 6.5 km (4 mile) bicycle-dedicated lane was opened, easing the traffic congestion between <a href="/wiki/Huilongguan" title="Huilongguan">Huilongguan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shangdi" title="Shangdi">Shangdi</a> where there are many high-tech companies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[245]</a></sup> Cycling has seen a resurgence in popularity spurred by the emergence of a large number of dockless app based <a href="/wiki/Bicycle-sharing_system" title="Bicycle-sharing system">bikeshares</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Mobike" title="Mobike">Mobike</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bluegogo" title="Bluegogo">Bluegogo</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ofo_(bike_sharing)" title="Ofo (bike sharing)">Ofo</a> since 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[246]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Defense_and_aerospace">Defense and aerospace</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=57" title="Edit section: Defense and aerospace">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Starting_aerial_formation_of_PRC70_Parade_(20191001112401).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4117" data-file-width="6175" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Starting_aerial_formation_of_PRC70_Parade_%2820191001112401%29.jpg/220px-Starting_aerial_formation_of_PRC70_Parade_%2820191001112401%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Starting_aerial_formation_of_PRC70_Parade_%2820191001112401%29.jpg/330px-Starting_aerial_formation_of_PRC70_Parade_%2820191001112401%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Starting_aerial_formation_of_PRC70_Parade_%2820191001112401%29.jpg/440px-Starting_aerial_formation_of_PRC70_Parade_%2820191001112401%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Starting_aerial_formation_of_PRC70_Parade_(20191001112401).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/KJ-2000" title="KJ-2000">KJ-2000</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chengdu_J-10" title="Chengdu J-10">J-10s</a> started the flypast formation on the <a href="/wiki/70th_anniversary_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="70th anniversary of the People's Republic of China">70th anniversary of the People's Republic of China</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The command headquarters of China's military forces are based in Beijing. The <a href="/wiki/Central_Military_Commission_(China)" title="Central Military Commission (China)">Central Military Commission</a>, the political organ in charge of the military, is housed inside the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Defense_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Ministry of National Defense of the People's Republic of China">Ministry of National Defense</a>, located next to the <a href="/wiki/Military_Museum_of_the_Chinese_People%27s_Revolution" title="Military Museum of the Chinese People's Revolution">Military Museum of the Chinese People's Revolution</a> in western Beijing. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Artillery_Corps" title="Second Artillery Corps">Second Artillery Corps</a>, which controls the country's <a href="/wiki/Intercontinental_ballistic_missile" title="Intercontinental ballistic missile">strategic missile</a> and nuclear weapons, has its command in <a href="/wiki/Qinghe_Subdistrict,_Beijing" title="Qinghe Subdistrict, Beijing">Qinghe</a>, Haidian District. The headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Theater_Command" title="Central Theater Command">Central Theater Command</a>, one of five nationally, is based further west in Gaojing. The CTR oversees the Beijing Capital Garrison as well as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/27th_Army_(People%27s_Republic_of_China)" title="27th Army (People's Republic of China)">27th</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/38th_Army_(People%27s_Republic_of_China)" title="38th Army (People's Republic of China)">38th</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/65th_Army_(People%27s_Republic_of_China)" title="65th Army (People's Republic of China)">65th Armies</a>, which are based in Hebei.
</p><p>Military institutions in Beijing also include academies and thinktanks such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PLA_National_Defence_University" title="PLA National Defence University">PLA National Defence University</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PLA_Academy_of_Military_Science" title="PLA Academy of Military Science">Academy of Military Science</a>, military hospitals such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/301_Military_Hospital" title="301 Military Hospital">301</a>, <a href="/wiki/307_Hospital" title="307 Hospital">307</a> and the Academy of Military Medical Sciences, and army-affiliated cultural entities such as 1 August Film Studios and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_People%27s_Liberation_Army_Naval_Song_and_Dance_Troupe" title="Chinese People's Liberation Army Naval Song and Dance Troupe">PLA Song and Dance Troupe</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/China_National_Space_Administration" title="China National Space Administration">China National Space Administration</a>, which oversees country's <a href="/wiki/Chinese_space_program" title="Chinese space program">space program</a>, and several space-related state owned companies such as <a href="/wiki/China_Aerospace_Science_and_Technology_Corporation" title="China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation">CASTC</a> and <a href="/wiki/China_Aerospace_Science_and_Industry_Corporation" title="China Aerospace Science and Industry Corporation">CASIC</a> are all based in Beijing. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beijing_Aerospace_Command_and_Control_Center" title="Beijing Aerospace Command and Control Center">Beijing Aerospace Command and Control Center</a>, in Haidian District tracks the country's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shenzhou_program" title="Shenzhou program">manned</a> and unmanned flight and other space exploration initiatives.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Nature_and_wildlife">Nature and wildlife</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=58" title="Edit section: Nature and wildlife">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Beijing Municipality has 20 nature reserves that have a total area of 1,339.7 km<sup>2</sup> (517.3 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[247]</a></sup> The mountains to the west and north of the city are home to a number of protected wildlife species including <a href="/wiki/Leopard" title="Leopard">leopard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leopard_cat" title="Leopard cat">leopard cat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wolf" title="Wolf">wolf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Red_fox" title="Red fox">red fox</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild boar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Masked_palm_civet" title="Masked palm civet">masked palm civet</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raccoon_dog" title="Raccoon dog">raccoon dog</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hog_badger" title="Hog badger">hog badger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siberian_weasel" title="Siberian weasel">Siberian weasel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amur_hedgehog" title="Amur hedgehog">Amur hedgehog</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roe_deer" title="Roe deer">roe deer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_rat_snake" title="Mandarin rat snake">mandarin rat snake</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[248]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[250]</a></sup> The Beijing Aquatic Wildlife Rescue and Conservation Center protects the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_giant_salamander" title="Chinese giant salamander">Chinese giant salamander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amur_stickleback" title="Amur stickleback">Amur stickleback</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_duck" title="Mandarin duck">mandarin duck</a> on the Huaijiu and Huaisha Rivers in <a href="/wiki/Huairou_District" title="Huairou District">Huairou District</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[251]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Milu_Yuan" title="Milu Yuan">Beijing Milu Park</a> south of the city is home to one of the largest herds of <a href="/wiki/P%C3%A8re_David%27s_deer" title="Père David's deer">Père David's deer</a>, now extinct in the wild. The <a href="/wiki/Beijing_barbastelle" title="Beijing barbastelle">Beijing barbastelle</a>, a species of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vesper_bat" title="Vesper bat">vesper bat</a> discovered in caves of <a href="/wiki/Fangshan_District" title="Fangshan District">Fangshan District</a> in 2001 and identified as a distinct species in 2007, is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endemic" title="Endemic">endemic</a> to Beijing. The mountains of Fangshan are also habitat for the more common <a href="/wiki/Beijing_mouse-eared_bat" title="Beijing mouse-eared bat">Beijing mouse-eared bat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Large_myotis" title="Large myotis">large myotis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greater_horseshoe_bat" title="Greater horseshoe bat">greater horseshoe bat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rickett%27s_big-footed_bat" title="Rickett's big-footed bat">Rickett's big-footed bat</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[252]</a></sup>
</p><p>Each year, Beijing hosts 200–300 species of <a href="/wiki/Bird_migration" title="Bird migration">migratory birds</a> including the <a href="/wiki/Common_crane" title="Common crane">common crane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Black-headed_gull" title="Black-headed gull">black-headed gull</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swan" title="Swan">swan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mallard" title="Mallard">mallard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_cuckoo" title="Common cuckoo">common cuckoo</a> and the endangered <a href="/wiki/Yellow-breasted_bunting" title="Yellow-breasted bunting">yellow-breasted bunting</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BJ_Evening_News_2016-10-30_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-BJ_Evening_News_2016-10-30-256">[254]</a></sup> In May 2016, Common cuckoos nesting in the wetlands of Cuihu (Haidian), Hanshiqiao (Shunyi), Yeyahu (Yanqing) were tagged and have been traced to far as India, Kenya and <a href="/wiki/Mozambique" title="Mozambique">Mozambique</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[256]</a></sup> In the fall of 2016, the Beijing Forest Police undertook a month-long campaign to crack down on illegal hunting and trapping of migratory birds for sale in local bird markets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BJ_Evening_News_2016-10-30_256-1"><a href="#cite_note-BJ_Evening_News_2016-10-30-256">[254]</a></sup> Over 1,000 rescued birds of protected species including <a href="/wiki/Streptopelia" title="Streptopelia">streptopelia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_siskin" title="Eurasian siskin">Eurasian siskin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crested_myna" title="Crested myna">crested myna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coal_tit" title="Coal tit">coal tit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Great_tit" title="Great tit">great tit</a> were handed to the Beijing Wildlife Protection and Rescue Center for repatriation to the wild.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BJ_Evening_News_2016-10-30_256-2"><a href="#cite_note-BJ_Evening_News_2016-10-30-256">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup>
</p><p>The city flowers are the <a href="/wiki/Rosa_chinensis" title="Rosa chinensis">Chinese rose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chrysanthemum" title="Chrysanthemum">chrysanthemum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cityflowertree_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-cityflowertree-260">[258]</a></sup> The city trees are the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_arborvitae" title="Chinese arborvitae">Chinese arborvitae</a>, an evergreen in the <a href="/wiki/Cypress" title="Cypress">cypress</a> <a href="/wiki/Cupressaceae" title="Cupressaceae">family</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pagoda_tree" title="Pagoda tree">pagoda tree</a>, also called the Chinese scholar tree, a <a href="/wiki/Deciduous" title="Deciduous">deciduous</a> tree of the family <a href="/wiki/Fabaceae" title="Fabaceae">Fabaceae</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cityflowertree_260-1"><a href="#cite_note-cityflowertree-260">[258]</a></sup> The oldest scholar tree in the city was planted in what is now <a href="/wiki/Beihai_Park" title="Beihai Park">Beihai Park</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[259]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="International_relations">International relations</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=59" title="Edit section: International relations">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>The capital is the home of the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Infrastructure_Investment_Bank" title="Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank">Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank</a>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multilateral_development_bank" title="Multilateral development bank">multilateral development bank</a> that aims to improve economic and social outcomes in Asia<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[260]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road_Fund" title="Silk Road Fund">Silk Road Fund</a>, an investment fund of the Chinese government to foster increased investment and provide financial supports in countries along the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/One_Belt,_One_Road" title="One Belt, One Road">One Belt, One Road</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[261]</a></sup> Beijing is also home to the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO)</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[262]</a></sup> making it an important city for <a href="/wiki/Diplomacy" title="Diplomacy">international diplomacy</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Twin_towns_and_sister_cities">Twin towns and sister cities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;section=60" title="Edit section: Twin towns and sister cities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_twin_towns_and_sister_cities_in_China" title="List of twin towns and sister cities in China">List of twin towns and sister cities in China</a></div><p>
Beijing is <a href="/wiki/Sister_city" title="Sister city">twinned</a> with the following regions, cities, and counties:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[263]</a></sup><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r998391716" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></p><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 20em;">
